revision.comment: /* Games */ removed section as not only unsourced but apparently discussing something other than the subject matter of this article. Balls catching fire in a video game have nothing to do with either probability, or with people's perceptions of probability.
revision.text:
{{about||pinball game|Hot Hand (pinball)|the hand-slapping game|Red hands}} The '''"hot hand"''' (also known as the '''"hot hand phenomenon"''' or '''"hot hand fallacy"''') is the purported phenomenon that a person who experiences a successful outcome with a [[Randomness|random]] event has a greater [[probability]] of success in further attempts. The concept is often applied to sports and skill-based tasks in general and originates from [[basketball]], whereas a shooter is allegedly more likely to score if their previous attempts were successful, i.e. while having "hot hands". While previous success at a task can indeed change the [[Psychology|psychological]] attitude and subsequent success rate of a player, researchers for many years did not find evidence for a "hot hand" in practice, dismissing it as [[fallacy|fallacious]]. However, later research questioned whether the belief is indeed a fallacy.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/faculty-research/working-papers/hot-hand-fallacy-cognitive-mistakes-or-equilibrium-adjustments|title=The Hot Hand Fallacy: Cognitive Mistakes or Equilibrium Adjustments? Evidence from Baseball |last=Green |first=Brett |last2=Zwiebel|first2=Jeffery|website=Stanford Graduate School of Business|access-date=2016-05-06}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite journal |last=Miller |first=Joshua B. |last2=Sanjurjo |first2=Adam |date=2016 |title=Surprised by the Gambler's and Hot Hand Fallacies? A Truth in the Law of Small Numbers |journal=IGIER Working Paper| number=552|doi=10.2139/ssrn.2627354}}</ref> Recent studies using modern statistical analysis show there is evidence for the "hot hand" in some sporting activities.<ref name=":0"/>
== Development of theory ==
=== 1985 "Hot Hand in Basketball" paper === The fallacy was first described in a 1985 paper by [[Amos Tversky]], [[Thomas Gilovich]], and Robert Vallone. The "Hot Hand in Basketball" study questioned the theory that basketball players have "hot hands", which the paper defined as the claim that players are more likely to make a successful shot if their previous shot was successful. The study looked at the inability of respondents to properly understand [[randomness]] and random events; much like [[innumeracy]] can impair a person's judgement of statistical information, the hot hand fallacy can lead people to form incorrect assumptions regarding random events. The three researchers provide an example in the study regarding the "coin toss"; respondents expected even short sequences of heads and tails to be approximately 50% heads and 50% tails.<ref name="Gilovich1985">{{cite journal|last=Gilovich|first=Thomas |author2=Tversky, A. |author3=Vallone, R.|title=The Hot Hand in Basketball: On the Misperception of Random Sequences|journal=Cognitive Psychology|year=1985|volume=17|issue=3|pages=295–314|doi=10.1016/0010-0285(85)90010-6}}</ref> The study proposed two biases that are created by the kind of thought pattern applied to the coin toss: it could lead an individual to believe that the probability of heads or tails increases after a long sequence of either has occurred (known as the [[gambler's fallacy]]); or it could cause an individual to reject randomness due to a belief that a streak of either outcome is not representative of a random sample.<ref name="Gilovich1985" />
The first study was conducted via a questionnaire of 100 basketball fans from the colleges of [[Cornell University|Cornell]] and [[Stanford University|Stanford]]. The other looked at the individual records of players from the [[1980–81 Philadelphia 76ers season|1980–81 Philadelphia 76ers]]. The third study analyzed free-throw data and the fourth study was of a controlled shooting experiment. The reason for the different studies was to gradually eliminate external factors around the shot. For example, in the first study there is the factor of how the opposing team's [[Basketball playbook|defensive strategy]] and shot selection would interfere with the shooter. The second and third take out the element of shot selection, and the fourth eliminates the game setting and the distractions and other external factors mentioned before. The studies primarily found that the outcomes of both field goal and free throw attempts are [[independence (probability theory)|independent]] of each other.<ref name="Gilovich1985" /> In the later studies involving the controlled shooting experiment the results were the same; evidently, the researchers concluded that the sense of being "hot" does not predict hits or misses.<ref name="Gilovich1985" />
=== Proposed explanations === Gilovich offers two different explanations for why people believe hot hands exist. The first is that a person may be [[bias]]ed towards looking for streaks before watching a basketball game. This bias would then affect their perceptions and recollection of the game ([[confirmation bias]]). The second explanation deals with people's inability to recognize chance sequences. People expect chance sequences to alternate between the options more than they actually do. Chance sequences can seem too lumpy, and are thus dismissed as non-chance ([[clustering illusion]]).
There are many proposed explanations for why people are susceptible to the hot-hand fallacy. Alan D. Castel, and others investigated the idea that age would alter an individual's belief in the fallacy.<ref name="Castel2012">{{cite journal|last=Castel|first=Alan |author2=Drolet Rossi, A. |author3=McGIllivary, S.|title=Beliefs About the "Hot Hand" in Basketball Across the Adult Life Span|journal=Psychology and Agin|volume=27 |issue=3 |pages=601–605 |year=2012|doi=10.1037/a0026991}}</ref> To test this idea researchers conducted a cross-sectional study where they sampled 455 participants ranging in age from 22 to 90 years old. These participants were given a questionnaire preceded by a prompt that said in college and professional basketball games no players make 100% of their attempted shots.<ref name="Castel2012" /> Then the questionnaire asked two important questions: (1) Does a basketball player have a better chance of making a shot after having just made the last two or three shots than after having missed the last two or three shots? (2) Is it important to pass the ball to someone who has just made several shots in a row?<ref name="Castel2012" />
The main interest of the questionnaire was to see if a participant answered yes to the first question, implying that they believed in the hot-hand fallacy. The results showed that participants over 70 years of age were twice as likely to believe the fallacy than adults 40–49,<ref name="Castel2012" /> confirming that the older individuals relied more on heuristic-based processes. Older adults are more likely to remember positive information, making them more sensitive to gains and less to losses than younger adults.<ref name="Castel2012" />
One study looked at the root of the hot-hand fallacy as being from an inability to appropriately judge sequences. The study compiled research from dozens of behavioral and cognitive studies that examined the hot-hand and gambler's fallacies with random mechanisms and skill-generated streaks. In terms of judging random sequences the general conclusion was that people do not have a statistically correct concept of random.<ref name="whats next">{{cite journal|last=Oskarsson|first=Van Boven|title=What's Next? Judging Sequences of Binary Events|journal=Psychological Bulletin|year=2009|volume=135|issue=2|pages=262–285|doi=10.1037/a0014821|pmid=19254080}}</ref> It concluded that human beings are built to see patterns in sensory and conceptual data of all types.<ref name="whats next" />
=== Follow up studies === A 2003 study by Koehler, J. J. & Conley C. A. was conducted to examine the hot hand in professional basketball. In this study the researchers examined film from the NBA shooting contests from 1994–1997. Through studying the film of the contests the researchers hoped to find evidence of sequential dependency within each shooter across all shots. They also searched for sequential dependencies within each shooter per set of 25 continuous shots, and employed a variety of novel techniques for isolating hot performance.<ref name="refmyth">{{cite journal|last=Koehler|first=Jonathan|year=2003|title=The "Hot Hand" Myth in Professional Basketball|journal=Journal of Sport Psychology|volume=2|issue=25|pages=253–259}}</ref> According to the hot hand a player should have very few runs and instead their hits and misses should be in clusters.
In their research there were only two players who had a significantly lower number of runs than expected by chance. No shooter had significantly more runs than would be expected by chance. About half of the shooters (12 of 23 = 52%) had fewer runs than expected, and about half (11 of 23 = 48%) had more runs than expected.<ref name="refmyth" /> The researchers also compared the shooters hits and misses. The data were more in accordance with chance than the hot hand. Through their analysis of the data the conclusion was drawn that there was nothing that supported the hot hand [[hypothesis]].
A study reported that a belief in the hot-hand fallacy affects a player's [[perception]]s of success.<ref name="ref2">{{cite journal | title=Raab, M., Gula, B., & Gigerenzer, G. (2011) | journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Applied | volume=18 | pages=81–94 | doi=10.1037/a0025951| year=2012 | last1=Raab | first1=Markus | last2=Gula | first2=Bartosz | last3=Gigerenzer | first3=Gerd }}</ref>
== Recent research in support of hot hand == More recent research has questioned the earlier findings, instead finding support for the belief of a hot hand phenomenon.
A 2003 paper from researchers at [[Monash University]] noted that Gilovich et al. did not examine the [[statistical power]] of their own experiments. By performing power analysis on the 1985 data, the researchers concluded that even if the Philadelphia 76ers did shoot in streaks, it is highly unlikely that Gilovich, Vallone and Tversky would have discovered that fact.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/~korb/iccs.pdf |title=The Story of The Hot Hand: Powerful Myth or Powerless Critique? |first=Kevin B. |last=Korb |first2=Michael |last2=Stillwell |year=2003 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927050854/http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/~korb/iccs.pdf |archivedate=2013-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
A paper from October 2011 by Yaari and Eisenmann, a large dataset of more than 300,000 NBA free throws were found to show "strong evidence" for the "hot hand" phenomenon at the individual level. They analyzed all free throws taken during five regular NBA seasons from 2005 to 2010. They found that there was a significant increase in players' probabilities of hitting the second shot in a two-shot series compared to the first one. They also found that in a set of two consecutive shots, the probability of hitting the second shot is greater following a hit than following a miss on the previous one.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0024532| pmid = 21998630| title = The Hot (Invisible?) Hand: Can Time Sequence Patterns of Success/Failure in Sports Be Modeled as Repeated Random Independent Trials?| journal = PLoS ONE| volume = 6| issue = 10| pages = e24532| year = 2011| last1 = Yaari | first1 = G. | last2 = Eisenmann | first2 = S. | bibcode = 2011PLoSO...624532Y | pmc=3187751}}</ref>
In November 2013, researchers at Stanford University used data from [[Major League Baseball]] and found that there was "strong evidence" that the hot hand existed in ten different statistical categories.<ref name=":1"/>
In 2014, a paper from three Harvard graduates presented at the Sloan Sports Analytics Conference, which used advanced statistics that for the first time could control for variables in basketball games such as the player's shot location and a defender's position, showed a "small yet significant hot-hand effect."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304071004579409071015745370|title=Does the 'Hot Hand' Exist in Basketball?|last=Cohen|first=Ben|date=2014-02-27|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-05-06}}</ref>
In 2015, an examination of the 1985 study by Joshua Miller and Adam Sanjurjo found flaws in the methodology of the 1985 study and showed that, in fact, the hot hands may exist. The researchers said that instead it may be attributable to a misapplication of statistical techniques.<ref name=":0"/> The authors concluded that people were right to believe that the hot hand exists in basketball.<ref name=":0"/>
== Hot hand in non-sport contexts ==
=== Consumers === There are places other than sport that can be affected by the hot-hand fallacy. A study conducted by Joseph Johnson et al. examined the characteristics of an individual's buying and selling behavior as it pertained to the hot hand and gambler's heuristic. Both of these occur when a consumer misunderstands random events in the market and is influenced by a belief that a small sample is able to represent the underlying process.<ref name="Johnson2005">{{cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Joseph|author2=Tellis, G.J. |author3=Macinnis, D.J. |title=Losers, Winners, and Biased Trades|journal=Journal of Consumer Research|year=2005|volume=2|issue=32|pages=324–329|doi=10.1086/432241}}</ref> To examine the effect of the hot hand and gambler's heuristic on the buying and selling behaviors of consumers, three hypotheses were made. Hypothesis one stated that consumers that were given stocks with positive and negative trends in earning would be more likely to buy a stock that was positive when it was first getting started but would become less likely to do so as the trend lengthened. Hypothesis two was that consumers would be more likely to sell a stock with negative earnings as the trend length initially increased but would decrease as the trend length increased more. Finally, the third hypothesis was that consumers in the buy condition would be more likely to choose a winning stock over those in the selling condition.<ref name="Johnson2005" />
The results of the experiment did not support the first hypothesis but did support hypotheses two and three, suggesting that the use of these heuristics is dependent on buying or selling and the length of the sequence.<ref name="Johnson2005" /> This means that those who had the shorter length and the buying condition would fall under the influence of the hot-hand fallacy. The opposite would be in accordance with the [[gambler's fallacy]] which has more of an influence on longer sequences of numerical information.
=== Gambling === A study was conducted to examine the difference between the hot-hand and [[gambler's fallacy]]. The gambler's fallacy is the expectation of a reversal following a run of one outcome.<ref name="sympathetic magic">{{cite journal | title= Roney, C. R., Trick, L. M. (2009)| journal= Sympathetic magic and perceptions of randomness: the hot hand versus the gambler's fallacy | volume= 15 | issue= 2 | pages= 197–210 |doi=10.1080/13546780902847137| year= 2009 | last1= Roney | first1= Christopher J. R. | last2= Trick | first2= Lana M. }}</ref> Gambler's fallacy occurs mostly in cases in which people feel that an event is random, such as rolling a pair of dice on a [[craps]] table or spinning the [[roulette]] wheel. It is caused by the false belief that the random numbers of a small sample will balance out the way they do in large samples; this is known as the law of small numbers heuristic. The difference between this and the hot-hand fallacy is that with the hot-hand fallacy an individual expects a run to continue.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Raab|first=Markus|author2=Gula, B. |author3=Gigerenzer, G. |title=The Hot hand Exists in Volleyball and Is Used for Allocation Decisions|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Applied|year=2011|volume=18|issue=1|pages=81–94|doi=10.1037/a0025951}}</ref> There is a much larger aspect of the hot hand that relies on the individual. This relates to a person's perceived ability to predict random events, which is not possible for truly random events. The fact that people believe that they have this ability is in line with the [[illusion of control]].<ref name="sympathetic magic" />
In this study, the researchers wanted to test if they could manipulate a [[Coin flipping|coin toss]], and counter the gambler's fallacy by having the participant focus on the person tossing the coin. In contrast, they attempted to initiate the hot-hand fallacy by centering the participant's focus on the person tossing the coin as a reason for the streak of either heads or tails. In either case the data should fall in line with [[sympathetic magic]], whereby they feel that they can control the outcomes of random events in ways that defy the [[Physical law|laws of physics]], such as being "hot" at tossing a specific randomly determined outcome.<ref name="sympathetic magic" />
They tested this concept under three different conditions. The first was person focused, where the person who tossed the coin mentioned that ''she'' was tossing a lot of heads or tails. Second was a coin focus, where the person who tossed the coin mentioned that ''the coin'' was coming up with a lot of heads or tails. Finally there was a control condition in which there was nothing said by the person tossing the coin.<ref name="sympathetic magic" /> The participants were also assigned to different groups, one in which the person flipping the coin changed and the other where the person remained the same.
The researchers found the results of this study to match their initial hypothesis that the gambler's fallacy could in fact be countered by the use of the hot hand and people's attention to the person who was actively flipping the coin. It is important to note that this counteraction of the gambler's fallacy only happened if the person tossing the coin remained the same.<ref name="sympathetic magic" /> This study shed light on the idea that the gambler's and hot hand fallacies at times fight for dominance when people try to make predictions about the ''same'' event.<ref name="sympathetic magic" />
== See also == * [[Apophenia]] * [[Clustering illusion]] * [[Gambler's fallacy]] * [[Game theory]] * [[Poisson distribution]] * [[Probability]] * [[Statistical randomness]] * [[Survivorship bias]] * [[Winning streak (sports)]]
== References == {{reflist|33em}}
== External links == * [http://www.hcrc.ed.ac.uk/cogsci2001/pdf-files/0152.pdf The Hot Hand in Basketball: Fallacy or Adaptive Thinking? - B.D. Burns] * [http://www.fallacyfiles.org/hothandf.html The Hot Hand Fallacy: Taxonomy of the Logical Fallacies] * [http://thehothand.blogspot.com/ Hot Hand website: Statistical analysis of sports streakiness]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Museum | name = Italian Basketball Hall of Fame | image = | imagesize = 250px | caption = | map_type = | map_caption = | latitude = | longitude = | established = [[2006 in sports#Basketball|2006]] | dissolved = | location = [[Bologna]], [[Italy]] | type = [[Hall of Fame]] | visitors = | chairperson = | president = | curator = | publictransit = | website = {{Official website|http://www.fip.it/halloffame/}} }} The '''Italian Basketball Hall of Fame''' ({{lang-it|Italia Basket Hall of Fame}}, IBHOF) is a [[hall of fame]] that honours individuals (or whole teams) that have contributed to the spread and improvement of Italian [[basketball]], through their sporting contributions, their behaviour and their actions in support of the game in [[Italy]].{{cite web |url=http://www.fip.it/halloffame/DocumentoNoList.asp?IDCartella=1698 |title=Mission - il più alto riconoscimento della Fip |author= |website=[[Federazione Italiana Pallacanestro|FIP]].it |access-date=13 September 2015 |language=Italian |trans-title=Mission - the highest honour from FIP}} The [[Federazione Italiana Pallacanestro|Italian Basketball Federation]] has inducted a class every year since 2007 (counting for the previous year) with an official ceremony that crowns athletes (male and female), coaches, referees or other figureheads who have contributed to Italian basketball, with a maximum of seven inductees per yer (teams exempted). Those also in the [[Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame|Naismith Hall of Fame]] or the [[FIBA Hall of Fame]] are not limited in number, in addition, two individuals who are deceased at most can also be inducted in memoriam yearly. ==History== The Hall of Fame was established by the [[Federazione Italiana Pallacanestro|Italian Basketball Federation]] (FIP) on 16 September 2006, with the first class (that of 2006) inducted on 11 February 2007 in [[Bologna]]. [[Sandro Riminucci]], who broke a [[Lega Basket Serie A|LBA]] record with 77 points in 1963, [[Sandro Gamba]], who had a hand in defeating the [[Soviet Union national basketball team]] at the [[Basketball at the 1980 Summer Olympics|1980 Olympics]], [[Gianfranco Lombardi|Dado Lombardi]] and [[Paolo Vittori]] were honoured, as well as [[Cesare Rubini]] (a [[Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame|Naismith Hall of Fame]] member like Gamba) and [[Dino Meneghin]] (in both the Naismith and [[FIBA Hall of Fame]]).{{cite web |url=http://www.fip.it/halloffame/DocumentoNoList.asp?IDCartella=485 |title=Classe 2006. La cerimonia - I 77 punti di Riminucci, Gamba che battè l'Unione Sovietica e le trasferte dell'epoca di Lombardi nei treni di terza classe |author= |date=11 February 2007 |website=[[Federazione Italiana Pallacanestro|FIP]].it |access-date=13 September 2015 |language=Italian |trans-title=Class of 2006. The ceremony - Riminucci's 77 points, Gamba beating the Soviet Union and the train trips in third class}} The 2008 class, inducted in Bologna on 22 February 2009, saw former [[Virtus Pallacanestro Bologna|Virtus Bologna]] [[head coach]] [[Ettore Messina]] amongst the inductees.{{cite web |url=http://www.fiba.com/news/ITA---New-class-inducted-for-Italia-Basket-Hall-of-Fame |title=ITA – New class inducted for Italia Basket Hall of Fame |author= |date=23 February 2009 |website=[[FIBA]].com |location=Bologna |access-date=13 September 2015}} The 2014 class, inducted in [[Rome]] on 23 March 2015, had a number of former [[Pallacanestro Varese]] members; [[Antonio Bulgheroni]] was crowned for his career both as Varese player (winning three LBA titles) and president (adding the 1999 title to become the only person to have won both as player and president), whilst [[Marino Zanatta]] and [[Fabrizio Della Fiori]] were honoured for their playing contributions to their [[sports club|clubs]] and the senior [[Italian national basketball team]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pallacanestrovarese.it/bulgheroni-zanatta-e-della-fiori-nella-italia-basket-hall-of-fame/ |title=Bulgheroni, Zanatta e Della Fiori nella Italia Basket Hall of Fame |author= |date=23 March 2015 |website=[[Pallacanestro Varese|PallacanestroVarese]].it |access-date=13 September 2015 |language=Italian |trans-title=Bulgheroni, Zanatta and Della Fiori in the Italian Basket Hall of Fame}} ==Inductees== {{Lega Basket Serie A awards}} ===Athletes=== The honour is bestowed on athletes that have distinguished themselves on the domestic or international front, with either a minimum of 50 or 30 national team [[cap (sports)|caps]] to respectively the [[Italy national basketball team|men's national team]] and the [[Italy women's national basketball team|women's national team]], an Italian domestic first division ([[Lega Basket Serie A|LBA]]) title, a European-wide cup title, or a medal at the senior [[EuroBasket]], [[FIBA World Cup]], or [[Basketball at the Summer Olympics|Summer Olympic Games]]. They have to have stopped playing for at least five years prior to the nomination.{{cite web |url=http://www.fip.it/halloffame/DocumentoDett.asp?IDDocumento=21560 |title=Il regolamento - Art. 3 – Categorie |author= |website=[[Federazione Italiana Pallacanestro|FIP]].it |access-date=13 September 2015 |language=Italian |trans-title=The rules: Art. 3 - categories}} {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width:60%" |- ! style="width:30%" |Male ! style="width:30%" |Female |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2006 |- | [[Sandro Gamba]] ('''{{Tooltip|N|Naismith Hall of Fame}}''') | - |- | [[Gianfranco Lombardi]] | - |- | [[Dino Meneghin]] ('''{{Tooltip|N|Naismith Hall of Fame}}''', '''{{Tooltip|F|FIBA Hall of Fame}}''') | - |- | [[Sandro Riminucci]] | - |- | [[Paolo Vittori]] | - |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2007 |- | [[Pierlo Marzorati]] ('''{{Tooltip|F|FIBA Hall of Fame}}''') | [[Mabel Bocchi]] |- | [[Gianfranco Pieri]] | - |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2008 |- | [[Ottorino Flaborea]] | [[Nidia Pausich]] |- | [[Aldo Ossola]] | - |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2009 |- | [[Giuseppe Brumatti]] | [[Nicoletta Persi]] |- | [[Giovanni Gavagnin]] | - |- | [[Giulio Iellini]] | - |- |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2010 |- | [[Massimo Masini]] | [[Lidia Gorlin]] |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2011 |- | [[Gabriele Vianello]] | [[Rosetta Bozzolo]] |- | [[Sauro Bufalini]] | - |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2012 |- | [[Renzo Bariviera]] | [[Wanda Sandon]] |- | [[Franco Bertini]] | - |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2013 |- | [[Carlo Caglieris]] | [[Catarina Pollini]] |- | [[Renato Villalta]] | - |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2014 |- | [[Fabrizio Della Fiori]] | [[Mara Fullin]] |- | [[Marino Zanatta]] | - |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2015 |- | [[Ivan Bisson]] | [[Bianca Rossi]] |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2016 |- | [[Massimo Cosmelli]] | - |- | [[Enrico Gilardi]] | - |- | [[Romeo Sacchetti]] | - |- ! colspan="2"|Class of 2017 |- | [[Oscar Schmidt]] | - |- |} ===Head coaches=== The honour is bestowed to [[head coaches]] who have distinguished themselves at home or abroad, winning either a medal at the senior [[EuroBasket]], [[FIBA World Cup]], or [[Basketball at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Summer Games]], a European-wide [[sports club|club]] competition, or the Italian first division title ([[Lega Basket Serie A|LBA]]) with either men's or women's teams and clubs. They have to be at least 65 years old at their nomination, and possess a national coaching license. Only one can be designated per year. {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width:40%" |- ! Class of 2006 |- | [[Cesare Rubini]] ('''{{Tooltip|N|Naismith Hall of Fame}}''', '''{{Tooltip|F|FIBA Hall of Fame}}''') |- ! Class of 2007 |- | [[Carlo Recalcati]] |- ! Class of 2008 |- | [[Ettore Messina]] |- ! Class of 2009 |- | [[Arnaldo Taurisano]] |- ! Class of 2010 |- | [[Tonino Zorzi]] |- ! Class of 2011 |- | [[Giuseppe Guerrieri]] |- ! Class of 2012 |- | [[Dan Peterson]] |- ! Class of 2013 |- | [[Valerio Bianchini]] |- ! Class of 2014 |- | [[Gianni Asti]] |- ! Class of 2015 |- | [[Alberto Bucci]] |- ! Class of 2016 |- | [[Bogdan Tanjević]] |} ===Teams=== The honour can be bestowed to an Italian basketball [[Sports club|club]] that has distinguished itself on the national or international scene, by winning Italian first division ([[Lega Basket Serie A|LBA]]) titles or European-wide cups, and who has through its actions and results, left a vivid memory to basketball followers. If the club is defunct, the prize can be received by a representative former member. It can also be awarded to an Italian national team ([[Italian national basketball team|men's]] or [[Italian women's national basketball team|women's]]), that has won a medal in a [[EuroBasket]], [[FIBA World Cup]], or [[Basketball at the Summer Olympics|Summer Olympic Games]]. {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width:100%" |- ! colspan="6"| Class of 2011 |- | colspan="6"| {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Italy national basketball team|Italy national men's team]] at the [[Basketball at the 1980 Summer Olympics|1980 Summer Olympic Games, in Moscow]] - {{silver medal}} |- | colspan="6"| '''Players''' |- |[[Fabrizio Della Fiori]] || [[Marco Solfrini]] || [[Marco Bonamico]] || [[Dino Meneghin]] || [[Renato Villalta]] || [[Renzo Vecchiato]] |- | [[Pierlo Marzorati]] || [[Pietro Generali (basketball)|Pietro Generali]] || [[Romeo Sacchetti]] || [[Roberto Brunamonti]] || [[Michael Sylvester (basketball player)|Michael Sylvester]] || [[Enrico Gilardi]] |- '''Staff''' | '''Head Coach'''
[[Sandro Gamba]] || '''Assistant Coach'''

[[Cesare Rubini]] |- ! colspan="6"| Class of 2013 |- | colspan="6"| {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Italy national basketball team|Italy national men's team]] at the [[EuroBasket 1983|1983 EuroBasket, in France]] - {{gold medal}} |- | colspan="6"| '''Players''' |- |[[Carlo Caglieris]] || [[Alberto Tonut]] || [[Marco Bonamico]] || [[Enrico Gilardi]] || [[Ario Costa]] || [[Roberto Brunamonti]] |- | [[Renato Villalta]] || [[Dino Meneghin]] || [[Antonello Riva]] || [[Renzo Vecchiato]] || [[Pierlo Marzorati]] || [[Romeo Sacchetti]] |- '''Staff''' | '''Head Coach'''

[[Cesare Rubini]] |- ! colspan="6"| Class of 2015 |- | colspan="6"| [[File:Pallacanestro Varese logo 2014.png|45px]] [[Pallacanestro Varese|Grande Ignis 1970–1979]] |- |- ! colspan="6"| Class of 2016 |- | colspan="6"|[[Pallacanestro Olimpia Milano|Olimpia Milano]] |- |} ===Referees=== The honour can be bestowed to [[Official (basketball)|referees]] who have distinguished themselves, at home or abroad, that have officiated for at least 10 years. They must have participated in at least a senior level [[EuroBasket]], [[FIBA World Cup]], [[Basketball at the Summer Olympics|Summer Olympic Games]], or a European-wide cup final for [[sports club|clubs]], for either men or women. The awardee must have stopped officiating for at least five years, prior to the award. Only one can be designated per year. {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width:40%" |- ! Class of 2007 |- | [[Aldo Albanesi]] |- ! Class of 2008 |- | [[Giancarlo Vitolo]] |- ! Class of 2009 |- | [[Vittorio Paolo Fiorito]] |- ! Class of 2010 |- | [[Ninì Ardito]] |- ! Class of 2011 |- | [[Bruno Duranti]] |- ! Class of 2012 |- | [[Stefano Cazzaro]] |} ===Contributors ("a life for basketball")=== The "a life for basketball" honour ({{lang-it|premio "una vita per il basket"}}), is awarded to those who have contributed significantly to the development of Italian basketball, be it domestically or internationally. They receive recognition for their actions in either Italian or international sports organisations. Any contributor who has been involved in Italian basketball, for at least twenty years, can be designated. There is a single designation per year, unless otherwise warranted by special circumstances. {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width:40%" |- ! Class of 2007 |- | [[Claudio Coccia]] |- | [[Gianluigi Porelli]] |- ! Class of 2008 |- | [[Aldo Vitale]] |- ! Class of 2009 |- | [[Gianni Corsolini]] |- ! Class of 2010 |- | [[Amedeo Salerno]] |- ! Class of 2011 |- | [[Valter Scavolini]] |- ! Class of 2012 |- | [[Gilberto Benetton]] |- ! Class of 2013 |- | [[Alessandro Galleani]] |- ! Class of 2014 |- | [[Antonio Bulgheroni]] |- | [[Raffaele Morbelli]] |- ! Class of 2015 |- | [[Achille Canna]] |} ===In memoriam=== The Italian Basketball Hall of Fame, can also honour deceased individuals, who have contributed significantly to the development of Italian basketball, be it domestically or internationally. A single awardee can be chosen each year, and nominations aren't accepted. The [[Italian Basketball Federation]] chooses the individual honoured in memoriam itself. {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width:40%" |- ! Class of 2007 |- | [[Aldo Giordani (basketball)|Aldo Giordani]] |- | [[Enrico Vinci]] |- ! Class of 2008 |- | [[Nello Paratore]] |- | [[Giancarlo Primo]] |- ! Class of 2009 |- | [[Adolfo Bogoncelli]] |- | [[Vittorio Tracuzzi]] |- ! Class of 2010 |- | [[Maurizio Martolini]] |- | [[Sergio Stefanini]] |- ! Class of 2014 |- | [[Diego Pini]] |} ==See also== *[[College Basketball Hall of Fame]] *[[Basketball Hall of Fame]] *[[FIBA Hall of Fame]] *[[French Basketball Hall of Fame]] *[[Finnish Basketball Hall of Fame]] *[[Australian Basketball Hall of Fame]] *[[Philippine Basketball Association Hall of Fame]] *[[Women's Basketball Hall of Fame]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.fip.it/halloffame/ Official website] {{it icon}} Retrieved 13 September 2015 {{Basketball in Italy}} {{Lega Basket Serie A}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Italian Basketball Hall of Fame}} [[Category:Awards established in 2006]] [[Category:Basketball in Italy]] [[Category:Basketball museums and halls of fame]] [[Category:Halls of fame in Italy]] [[Category:2006 establishments in Italy]] [[Category:European basketball awards]]

{{Infobox martial art | image =Lutadores.jpg | imagesize = 250px | name = Luta Livre | focus = [[Grappling]] | country = {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Brazil]] | creator = [[Euclydes Hatem]] | parenthood = [[Catch Wrestling]], [[Judo]] | famous_pract = [[Marco Ruas]]
[[Johil de Oliveira]]
[[Hugo Duarte]]
[[Eugenio Tadeu]]
[[Alexandre Franca Nogueira]]
Nicolas Renier
Marcelo "Cromado"
[[Gesias Cavalcante]]
[[Alexandre Ferreira (fighter)|Alexandre Ferreira]]
[[Terry Etim]]
[[Rousimar Palhares]]
[[Milton Vieira]]
[[Murilo Bustamante]]
[[Pedro Rizzo]]
[[Renato Sobral]]
[[Jose Aldo]]
[[Darren Till]] | olympic = No }} '''Luta Livre''' ({{IPA-pt|ˈlutɐ ˈlivɾi|lang}}, lit. ''freestyle fighting''), also referred as '''Luta Livre Brasileira''' or '''Luta Livre Submissa''', is a Brazilian martial art created by [[Euclydes Hatem]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lutalivre.net/home126.html|title=Andyconda Luta Livre - the art of grappling and MMA - Luta-Livre brazilian Grappling and MMA|work=lutalivre.net}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lutalivre-academy.de/publications/articles/the-development-of-luta-livre-and-vale-tudo-in-brazil-part-ii-1/|title=RFT Deutschland - The development of Luta Livre and Vale Tudo in Brazil. Part II|publisher=|accessdate=4 August 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/653980-history-of-jiu-jitsu-baptism-by-fire-and-luta-livre|title=History of Jiu Jitsu: Baptism By Fire and Luta Livre|author=Tom|work=Bleacher Report|accessdate=4 August 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bloodyelbow.com/2009/1/10/710938/mma-history-xviii-the-loss|title=MMA History XVIII: The Losses of Luta Livre|author=Nate Wilcox|work=Bloody Elbow|accessdate=4 August 2015}} in Rio de Janeiro. Primarily a mixture of [[catch wrestling]] and [[judo]], there is also [[Strike (attack)|striking]] with the hands, feet, knees and elbows. Notable practitioners include [[Marco Ruas]], [[Ebenezer Fontes Braga]], [[Johil de Oliveira]], [[Alexandre Franca Nogueira]], [[Renato Sobral]], [[Darren Till]] and [[José Aldo]]. There are two styles: ''esportiva'' ("sporting") and ''[[vale tudo]]'' ("anything goes"); both styles are [[no-gi]]. In ''esportiva'' competitions, grappling techniques are the only techniques allowed to subdue the opponent. Consequently, it is important to calmly strategize and execute moves with the aim to force the opponent to submit via [[armlock]], [[leglock]], [[chokehold|choke]] or [[necklock]], or to [[points decision|win by points]] (i.e. [[Takedown (grappling)|takedowns]], domination position). Punches, kicks and other "hard" techniques are not allowed as this is considered more a sport than actual combat. ''Vale tudo'', on the other hand, includes techniques in the clinch as well as on the ground; punches and kicks are allowed, but the ground fight and submissions are still the largest elements. This is also the form used in [[Mixed martial arts|MMA]]-style fights. ==History== Luta Livre's founder is credited to be [[Euclydes Hatem|Euclydes "Tatu" Hatem]], who was originally a [[catch wrestling|catch wrestler]]. Euclydes Hatem went by the name of Tatu. [http://martialarts.about.com/od/styles/a/lutalivre.htm] He began teaching catch wrestling techniques to others in [[Rio de Janeiro]] in 1927 while experimenting with some of his own innovative techniques.{{cite web|url=http://www.amithakim.com/49279/The-Founder-Tatu|title=讛讗转专 讛专砖诪讬 砖诇 注诪讬转 讞讻讬诐 - The Founder - Tatu|work=amithakim.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826115958/http://www.amithakim.com/49279/The-Founder-Tatu|archivedate=2014-08-26|df=}} Tatu brought on many challenges with the Braziliian Jiujitsu and culminated with his victory over George Gracie in the Catch rules fight.The style emphasized fighting without a gi/uniform. He received popularity when he submitted George Gracie in 1940 and when one of his students, [[Euclides Pereira]] defeated [[Carlson Gracie]] in 1968.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloodyelbow.com/2009/1/10/710938/mma-history-xviii-the-loss|title=MMA History XVIII: The Losses of Luta Livre|work=Bloody Elbow}} The system focused on [[ground fighting]] and submissions due to their importance in [[Vale Tudo]] matches. The groundfighting included the use of leg locks, which at the time was ignored by Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. For years, Luta Livre was extremely popular in Brazil, second only to Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. [http://www.fightmagazine.com/mma-magazine/back-to-brazil-2104/] Some of the famous fighters that came out of Luta Livre included William Porfirio.{{cite web|url=http://www.sherdog.com/fighter/William-Porfirio-15725|title=William|work=Sherdog|accessdate=4 August 2015}} In the 1970s Luta Livre was strongly influenced by father and son duo Fausto and Carlos Brunocilla. The Brunocilla were Tatu's pupils and were in turn responsible for graduating many Luta Livre Masters. Also around the 1970s, the art of Luta Livre was influenced by [[Roberto Leitão]], a practitioner of judo and wrestling.{{cite web|url=http://www.bjjee.com/articles/history-of-luta-livre-reasons-for-lack-of-mainstream-popularity/|title=History Of Luta Livre & Reasons For Lack Of "Mainstream" Popularity|work=Bjj Eastern Europe}} Leitao also articulated the "Theory of Grappling", sometimes referred to as "Theory of Luta Livre". Roberto Leitao was a University professor of Engineering{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} who had devoted many years to [[Wrestling]] and Judo. ==Ranking== The grading system, according to the Wrestling Federation Submission of the State of Rio de Janeiro, is divided into three: beginners, intermediate and advanced. '''Beginners''' *White. *Yellow. *Orange. '''Intermediate''' *Blue. '''Advanced''' *Purple. *Brown. *Black. ==Luta Livre and Brazilian jiu-jitsu== Luta Livre, in its early days, was largely considered to be an art "for poor kids who could not afford a gi." {{cite web|url=http://www.bloodyelbow.com/2012/3/11/2848189/mma-origins-brazilian-warfare-MMA-History|title=MMA Origins: Brazilian Warfare|author=T.P. Grant|work=Bloody Elbow|accessdate=4 August 2015}} due to appearances since they didn't fight with a [[Brazilian jiu-jitsu gi|gi]]. Luta Livre and BJJ were considered to be enemies. When Euclides Perreria beat Carlson Gracie in 1968 {{Citation needed|date=July 2017}}, the rivalry was continued for a few more decades. It was actually very popular amongst kids from the favelas. [http://sports.espn.go.com/extra/mma/columns/story?id=6085794] Luta Livre focused on teaching the poor who were primarily of African descent.{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/653980-history-of-jiu-jitsu-baptism-by-fire-and-luta-livre|title=History of Jiu Jitsu: Baptism By Fire and Luta Livre|author=Tom|work=Bleacher Report}} This was opposed to Brazilian Jiujitsu which was thought to focus on teaching of the upper class, who were primarily light skinned. The battles between the two arts was essentially a class warfare.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloodyelbow.com/2012/3/18/2882727/video-bjj-jiu-jitsu-vs-luta-livre-desafio-matches-rivalry-bustamante-ismail-maia-tadeu-gurgel-maia|title=Video: The Three Historic Challenge Matches From Desafio - Jiu-Jitsu Vs. Luta Livre|work=Bloody Elbow}} By the 1980s, [[Gracie Jiu-Jitsu]] had become very popular in [[Brazil]] and Luta Livre representatives wanted to help popularize their art by accepting challenges from Brazilian jiu-jitsu champions in [[Vale Tudo]] and Submission matches. Luta Livre continued on with many famous fights in and out of the ring. This included a fight with [[Rickson Gracie]] on the beaches of Brazil.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/extra/mma/columns/story?id=6085794|title=Brazil versus Brazil, MMA's most intense rivalry|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=4 August 2015}} This would hurt Luta Livre's reputation with [[Hugo Duarte]] losing to [[Rickson Gracie]] then getting knocked out by [[Tank Abbott]] at [[UFC 17]] and [[Eugenio Tadeu]] losing to [[Wallid Ismael]] due to his inability to re-enter the ring in time. Tadeu did battle [[Royler Gracie]] to a draw in an indoor fight. Another fight between [[Renzo Gracie]] and Eugenio Tadeu kept the rivalry going. [http://sports.espn.go.com/extra/mma/columns/story?id=6085794] His battle with [[Renzo Gracie]] in 1997 ended in a No Contest due to fans rioting. In 1991 [[Desafio]] hosted a Jiu-Jitsu vs Luta Livre card that had three representatives of Brazilian jiu-jitsu up against three representatives of Luta Livre, with BJJ winning all three fights. One fighter [[Marco Ruas]], who would later become a UFC champ, had a huge rivalry with [[Rickson Gracie]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bloodyelbow.com/2007/8/7/15283/31501|title=The Ur-Brazilian MMA Feud: BJJ vs Luta Livre and the Style They Never Saw Coming|author=Nate Wilcox|work=Bloody Elbow|accessdate=4 August 2015}} A fight though never occurred between the two fighters. When MMA became popularized and after BJJ having such success against Luta Livre practitioners in the more popular MMA fights, more Luta Livre practitioners left their original camps and went instead to the Jiu-Jitsu camps hoping for success in a fighting career. Hugo, Johil De Oliveira, and Eugenio Tadeau are amongst the most notable representatives of that era for the Luta Livre style that was famous for opposing against Brazilian Jiu-jitsu in the Vale Tudo events held in Brazil. Despite their overall losses against Jiu-Jitsu, Luta Livre seems to be making a resurgence in mixed martial arts.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloodyelbow.com/2012/5/26/3045234/luta-livre-mma-bjj-marcelo-brigadeiro-resurgence-renovacao-fight-team-kaobon-sass-betao-falcao|title=Marcelo Brigadeiro On The Resurgence Of Luta Livre Fighters In MMA|work=Bloody Elbow}} ==See also== *[[Lucha Libre]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.lutalivre-academy.de Renovação Fight Team Deutschland (Germany)] * [http://www.lutalivre-academy.de/publications/articles/the-development-of-luta-livre-and-vale-tudo-in-brazil-part-i-1/ Complete History of Luta Livre] *[http://www.lutalivre.net/ International Luta Livre (Esportiva-Vale Tudo) Federation] *[http://www.lutalivresubmission.com.br/ Federação de Luta-Livre Submission do Estado do Rio de Janeiro] *[http://www.luta-livre.de/ European Luta Livre (Esportiva-Vale Tudo) Federation] {{Martial arts}} {{Luta Livre |state=expanded}} [[Category:Brazilian martial arts]] [[Category:Sports originating in Brazil]] [[Category:Mixed martial arts styles]] [[category:Combat sports]]

{{Refimprove|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Market Square Arena | nickname = | image = Market Square Arena 1982.jpg | caption = Market Square Arena in 1982 | location = 300 East Market Street
[[Indianapolis|Indianapolis, Indiana]] 46204 | coordinates = {{coord|39|46|6|N|86|9|7|W|type:landmark_scale:1000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = October 20, 1971 | opened = September 15, 1974 | renovated = 1995 | expanded = | closed = October 24, 1999 | demolished = July 8, 2001 | owner = [[Indianapolis|City of Indianapolis]] | operator = [[Indianapolis|City of Indianapolis]] | surface = Multi-surface | construction_cost = $23 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|23000000|1974}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Architects 4 (A Joint Venture):
Kennedy, Brown & Associates
Fleck, Burkart, Shropshire, Boots, Reid & Associates
McGuire & Shook Corporation[http://www.modernsteel.com/archives/PDFs_61-90/1975A9_15-4.pdf] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101218024645/http://www.modernsteel.com/archives/PDFs_61-90/1975A9_15-4.pdf |date=December 18, 2010 }} | structural engineer = J. Robert Carlton & Associates Inc. | general_contractor = [[Hunt Construction Group|Huber, Hunt & Nichols]] | former_names = | tenants = [[Indiana Pacers]] ([[National Basketball Association|NBA]]) (1974–1999)
[[Indianapolis Racers]] ([[World Hockey Association|WHA]]) (1974–1978)
[[Indianapolis Checkers]] ([[International Hockey League (1945–2001)|IHL]]) (1985–1987)
[[Indianapolis Ice]] (IHL) (1994–1998)
[[Indiana Twisters]] ([[Continental Indoor Soccer League|CISL]]) (1996–1997) | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]]: 16,530
[[Ice hockey]]: 15,993 }} '''Market Square Arena''' was an [[indoor arena]] in [[Indianapolis]]. Completed in 1974, at a cost of $23 million, it seated 16,530 for [[basketball]] and 15,993 for [[ice hockey]]. Seating capacity for concerts and other events was adjusted by the use of large curtains which sealed off the upper rows. ==History== In the late 1960s, the city of Indianapolis studied several market areas of the city for future development and revitalization. Students from the fourth-year design studio class at [[Ball State University College of Architecture and Planning]] met with the City of Indianapolis to review and select 20–26 projects for consideration. Students Joseph Mynhier and Terry Pastorino selected downtown Indianapolis as their market and designed what would become Market Square Arena. The design envisioned by Mynhier and Pastorino was later selected and used as a promotional tool by the City of Indianapolis for construction of the stadium. The city selected four architectural firms to complete the arena design with two representatives from each of the four companies. Terry Pastorino, who had worked for Kennedy, Brown & Trueblood, Inc., during the summer of 1970 on the project, later joined the firm working on the arena. The original student design included a four-story office building covering two city blocks. The Market Square Arena as constructed consisted of a unique space frame design spanning Market Street. The playing floor was elevated over Market Street by a parking garage on each side of Market Street. Market Street terminated at Market Square Arena to the east and to the west by the capitol. The final design eventually took up one city block spanning Market Street. Market Square Arena's original center-hung scoreboard was an American Sign and Indicator scoreboard similar to those which would be installed at [[Arizona Veterans Memorial Coliseum]] and [[Joe Louis Arena]]. Its replacement, a center-hung White Way Sign scoreboard with a color matrix screen on each side (the AS&I scoreboard had monochrome matrix screens), was installed in time for the [[1985 NBA All-Star Game]] and remained at the arena for the rest of its life, where it would later be complimented by front-projection video screens on each end of the arena (complete with [[RCA]] projectors). ===Demolition=== The Pacers moved to the new [[Conseco Fieldhouse]] for the [[1999–2000 NBA season]], and Market Square Arena was demolished on July 8, 2001, in a multimillion-dollar implosion.{{cite news|url=http://www2.indystar.com/library/MSA/msa09.html|title=Much Relief, Very Little Damage as Implosion Goes Like Clockwork|first=Doug|last=Sword|newspaper=[[Indianapolis Star]]|date=July 8, 2001|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010052947/http://www2.indystar.com/library/MSA/msa09.html|archivedate=October 10, 2007|df=}} It only took 12 seconds to demolish the arena completely. Prior to the demolition, the basketball court surface was removed. It is now housed at the [[National Institute for Fitness and Sport]] in [[White River State Park]].{{cite web|title=Fitness Center Facilities|url=http://nifs.web13.hubspot.com/fitness-center/fitness-center-facilities/|work=NIFS website|accessdate=21 August 2013}} The site of the former arena was a parking lot for over a decade. The parking lot held a memorial to [[Elvis Presley]], who played his final concert at MSA on June 26, 1977. The memorial was designed and built by Alan Clough. In January 2017, [[Cummins]] opened their Global Distribution Headquarters on the southern half of the site.{{cite news|title=Cummins cuts ribbon on downtown Indy headquarters|url=http://fox59.com/2017/01/05/cummins-cuts-ribbon-on-downtown-indy-headquarters/|author=McQuaid, Russ|website=[[WXIN|Fox 59]]|date=5 January 2017|accessdate=14 January 2017}} A 28-story apartment building named 360 Market Square and containing a {{convert|40000|sqft|adj=on}} [[Whole Foods Market]] store opened in March 2018, with the Elvis memorial placed on the sidewalk adjacent to the building.{{cite news|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/entertainment/music/2018/06/26/elvis-presley-final-concert-plaque-back-home-revamped-market-street-indianapolis/732048002/|title=You can now find Elvis Presley final-concert plaque amid shiny new spots on Market Street|first=David|last=Lindquist|newspaper=[[Indianapolis Star]]|date=June 27, 2018|accessdate=12 September 2018}} ===Capacity=== {{col-begin}}{{col-break}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Basketball |- ! style="{{NBA color cell|Indiana Pacers}}"|Years ! style="{{NBA color cell|Indiana Pacers}}"|Capacity |- ! style="{{NBA color cell2|Indiana Pacers}}"|1974–1982 |
17,000
|- ! style="{{NBA color cell2|Indiana Pacers}}"|1982–1985 |
17,096
|- ! style="{{NBA color cell2|Indiana Pacers}}"|1985–1991 |
16,912
|- ! style="{{NBA color cell2|Indiana Pacers}}"|1991–1999 |
16,530
|} {{col-break}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Hockey |- ! Years ! Capacity |- | style=text-align:center|'''1974–1999''' |
15,993
|} {{col-end}} ==Events== Market Square Arena was best known as the home of the [[Indiana Pacers]] of the [[American Basketball Association]] and [[National Basketball Association]] from 1974 to 1999. The first Pacers basketball game held in the arena was a preseason game against the [[Milwaukee Bucks]]; attendance was 16,929. The first regular-season ABA game in the arena was held on October 18, 1974, against the [[San Antonio Spurs]]; the Pacers lost in double overtime, 129–121 in front of 7,473 fans. The first Pacers victory in Market Square Arena came on October 23 with a 122–107 win over the [[Spirits of St. Louis]]. The 1974–75 season ended for the Pacers with the ABA Finals played in Market Square Arena and [[Freedom Hall]] against their archrivals, the [[Kentucky Colonels]]. The Colonels defeated the Pacers in that championship series, winning the ABA title in five games (4 wins to 1). The 1975–76 Pacers won their final home ABA game in Market Square Arena with a 109–95 victory against the Colonels. (Kentucky won the next game by one point to win the series and advance, ending the Pacers' ABA tenure.) The Pacers played in Market Square Arena after they joined the NBA. [[Michael Jordan]]'s return to the [[Chicago Bulls]] after his first retirement took place at Market Square Arena in a loss to the Pacers on March 19, 1995.{{cite web|url=http://www.jumpman23.ch/joc_10_mj_02.jpg |format=JPG |title=Basketball photograph |publisher=Jumpman23.ch |accessdate=2015-05-09}} The final Pacers game played in Market Square Arena was a pre-season exhibition game against the [[Utah Jazz]] on October 23, 1999. [[File:Market Square Arena, Indianapolis, 1988.jpg|thumb|left|Market Square Arena in 1988]] The arena also hosted the [[1980 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1980 NCAA men's basketball Final Four]] & the [[Horizon League|Midwestern Collegiate Conference]] (now Horizon League) men's basketball conference tournament from 1986 to 1988 and again in 1993. In 1987, Indianapolis hosted the [[1987 Pan American Games|Pan American Games]], and the [[Basketball at the 1987 Pan American Games|basketball event]] was held at Market Square. The gold-medal game pitted Brazil against the United States. The U.S. team of college players featured two All-Americans in [[David Robinson (basketball)|David Robinson]] and [[Danny Manning]], two Final Four MVPs in [[Pervis Ellison]] and [[Keith Smart]], and several other future NBA players. The U.S. team led 68–54 at halftime, but [[Oscar Schmidt]] led Brazil to a stunning comeback, finishing with 46 points as Brazil won 120–115. Market Square Arena was the primary concert venue for virtually all national and international musical acts visiting Indiana until its demolition in 2001. While many concerts moved to the Deer Creek Music Center amphitheatre during summer months after that venue opened in 1989, Market Square remained the primary concert venue for large acts visiting the city of Indianapolis. Market Square hosted acts from [[Elvis Presley]] and [[Frank Sinatra]] to [[Eric Clapton]], [[Kenny Rogers]], [[Deep Purple]], [[Cheap Trick]], [[Kiss (band)|KISS]], and several Black Expo performances. Other events held at Market Square included [[circus]]es, [[Ice Capades]], [[monster truck]] shows, indoor [[motocross]] racing, [[rodeo]]s, etc. Market Square Arena was also the home of the [[Indianapolis Racers]] of the [[World Hockey Association|WHA]] from 1974 to 1979. 17-year-old [[Wayne Gretzky]] starred for the Racers in his first professional action before being traded to the [[Edmonton Oilers]] after a handful of games. ===Notable events=== The first event held at the arena was a [[Glen Campbell]] concert on September 15, 1974.{{cite web |url=http://www.ballparks.phanfare.com/2414480 |title=Market Square Arena – Indianapolis, Indiana – Ballparks, Arenas and Stadiums – Powered by Phanfare |publisher=Ballparks.phanfare.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518081909/http://www.ballparks.phanfare.com/2414480 |archivedate=2015-05-18 |df= }} [[Elvis Presley]] performed his final live concert here, in front of 18,000 people, on June 26, 1977, seven weeks before his death.{{cite web|last1=Lindquist|first1=David|title=Elvis Presley provoked cheers, jeers at final concert|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/06/26/elvis-presley-drew-cheers-jeers-1977-concert/426828001/|publisher=''[[The Indianapolis Star]]''|accessdate=26 December 2017|date=26 June 2017}} The [[Bee Gees]] performed here on July 26, 1979 as part of their [[Spirits Having Flown Tour]]. [[Billy Graham]]'s 1980 Indiana Crusade, featuring a young [[Bill Gaither (gospel singer)|Bill Gaither]] as one of the musical guests, was the most attended event at the arena in its history. [[Pat Benatar]] performed during her Precious Time tour on August 19, 1981. [[Mötley Crüe]] filmed their music video for "[[Wild Side (Mötley Crüe song)|Wild Side]]" here on July 18, 1987, which contains footage of drummer [[Tommy Lee]]'s spinning drum cage. [[Andre The Giant]] won the [[WWE World Heavyweight Championship|WWF Heavyweight Championship]], ending [[Hulk Hogan]]'s first reign. This was televised live on [[NBC]]'s [[WWF The Main Event|The Main Event]] on February 5, 1988. [[Michael Jackson]] performed two consecutive sold–out shows at Market Square Arena, during his [[Bad (tour)|Bad World Tour]] on March 18–19, 1988. [[Kiss (band)|KISS]]' show on November 28, 1992, was recorded and released as a live album, entitled ''[[Alive III]]''. [[Wayne Gretzky]] first skated out on the ice to start his pro hockey career. [[Michael Jordan]] made his comeback from retirement in 1995. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060524130351/http://www2.indystar.com/library/MSA/video.html Video of MSA's demolition] – Video Collection of the demolition by ''[[The Indianapolis Star]]'' *[http://lostindiana.net/2001/07/08/market-square-arena-indianapolis/ Lost Indiana profile of Market Square Arena] {{Navboxes|list1= {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Indiana Pacers]] | years = 1974–1999 | before = [[Fairgrounds Coliseum|Indiana State Fair Coliseum]] | after = [[Conseco Fieldhouse]] }} {{succession box | title = [[NCAA]] [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|Men's Division I]]
[[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|Basketball Tournament]]
Finals Venue | years = [[1980 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1980]] | before = [[Jon M. Huntsman Center|Special Events Center]] | after = [[Spectrum (arena)|Spectrum]] }} {{end}} {{Indiana Pacers}} {{IUPUI Jaguars men's basketball navbox}} }} [[Category:1974 establishments in Indiana]] [[Category:1999 disestablishments in Indiana]] [[Category:American Basketball Association venues]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct indoor arenas in Indiana]] [[Category:Defunct indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct indoor soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Former National Basketball Association venues]] [[Category:Demolished music venues in Indiana]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in Indiana]] [[Category:Indiana Pacers venues]] [[Category:IUPUI Jaguars men's basketball]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1974]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 2001]] [[Category:Sports venues in Indianapolis]] [[Category:World Hockey Association venues]] [[Category:Ice hockey venues in Indiana]] [[Category:Buildings and structures demolished by controlled implosion]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox rugby team | teamname = Olivos | image = Olivos RC logo.png | imagesize = 110px | location = [[Munro, Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] | countryflag = ARG | fullname = Olivos Rugby Club | union = [[Unión de Rugby de Buenos Aires|URBA]] | shortname = | nickname = | founded = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1927|9|4}} | ground = Mariano Pelliza, Munro | url = http://www.olivosrugbyclub.com.ar/ | president = Hernán Grosse | coach = Juan González Vidal
Juan Pérez Pardo | league = Primera B | season = 2017 | position = 3° (Promoted) |pattern_la1=_black_hoops|pattern_b1=_blackhoops|pattern_ra1=_black_hoops|leftarm1=ff7700|body1=ff7700|rightarm1=ff7700|shorts1=FFFFFF| pattern_so1=_hoops_black|socks1=ff7700 }} '''Olivos Rugby Club''' is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] [[rugby union]] and [[field hockey]] club located in [[Munro, Buenos Aires]]. The rugby team is member of the [[Unión de Rugby de Buenos Aires]] (URBA), having won its only [[Torneo de la URBA|URBA championship]] in 1940. Olivos currently competes in Primera División B, the second division of the URBA league system. Olivos' hockey teams are affiliated to [[Buenos Aires Hockey Association]] (AHBA), competing in championships organised by the body. ==History== The sporting institution was founded on September 4, 1927 as a rugby club by 20 young men of the Vicente López district. Although the club is located in [[Munro, Buenos Aires|Munro]], it bears the name of nearby [[Olivos, Buenos Aires Province|Olivos]], the seat of the Vicente López district. One of the founders of the club was young Alejandro Bowers who came from a wealthy background. His father, Don Carlos Bowers, would become a major benefactor and the club's colours of Orange and Black were chosen in his honour. After a couple of friendly games the club would enter the third level of the URBA championship in 1929, reach the first level in 1933 and win their first, and so far only, URBA title in 1940. Since then, the club has been a constant feature in the league, fielding teams at all levels. ===Honours=== *'''[[Torneo de la URBA]] (1)''': 1940 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.olivosrugbyclub.com.ar/ Official site] {{Commons cat|Olivos Rugby Club}} {{URBA Tournament}} [[Category:Argentine rugby union teams]] [[Category:Rugby clubs established in 1927]] [[Category:Argentine field hockey clubs]] [[Category:1927 establishments in Argentina]] {{Argentina-rugbyunion-team-stub}}

revision.comment: [[WP:RBK|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/SydneyThomason|SydneyThomason]] ([[User talk:SydneyThomason|talk]]) to last version by Bbb23 not noteworthy
revision.text:
'''Omniturf''' is a brand of sand in-filled second-generation [[artificial turf]],<ref name=bnoicwoaf>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4h9ZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=noYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2277%2C4820522 |newspaper=The Bulletin |location=Bend, Oregon |agency=UPI |last=Roffo |first=Dave |title=Battle now on in competitive world of artificial fields |date=June 6, 1985 |page=D-1 }}</ref> It was the first artificial surface to be used by an [[English Football League]] club.
==United Kingdom== The first club to install this 'plastic grass' surface was [[Queens Park Rangers F. C.|Queens Park Rangers]] who installed the new pitch for the start of the 1981/82 season.<ref>{{cite web | title=Jim Gregory R.I.P. | url=http://www.queensparkrangersfc.com/gregory.htm | work=Unofficial QPR Hall of Fame | publisher= | date= | accessdate=2009-06-02}}</ref> Despite much publicity around the supposed unfair advantage the pitch would provide Rangers, they proceeded to lose the opening home Division Two match on the new surface by 1-2 against [[Luton Town F. C.|Luton Town]].
The pitch did prove to be successful for Rangers though, as they reached the [[FA Cup]] Final in the 1981/82 season (as a 2nd Division club), and then won the (old) 2nd Division Championship the following season.
The innovation at [[Loftus Road]] brought mixed results, for while the ball ran smoothly enough over the hard surface, it was unpredictable when allowed to bounce. This caused confusion among defenders and goalkeepers in particular.<ref>{{cite news | title=The pitch may be artificial but the need for a point is genuine | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/oct/13/sport.comment2 | work=The Guardian.co.uk | publisher= | date=2007-10-13 | accessdate=2009-06-02 | location=London | first=David | last=Lacey}}</ref>
The Omniturf pitch lasted at Rangers' [[Loftus Road]] ground for seven seasons; the pitch was torn up at the end of the 1987/88 season.
Other Football League clubs which also laid similar artificial surfaces during the 1980s were Luton Town, [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]], and [[Preston North End F. C.|Preston North End]].
==United States== For [[American football]], Omniturf was installed several [[college football]] stadiums in the [[United States]]. Its first major venue was [[Autzen Stadium]] at the [[University of Oregon]] in [[Eugene, Oregon|Eugene]] in 1984.<ref name=augasnew>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6uhVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=keEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6245%2C6549368 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |title=Autzen getting a sandy, new turf |agency=wire services |date=June 27, 1984 |page=1C}}</ref><ref name=rghtstf>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=roRTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oYYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4150%2C5246623 |newspaper=The Bulletin |location=Bend, Oregon |title=Omni Turf, right stuff? |date=November 5, 1984 |page=D-3 }}</ref><ref name=iatstgrs>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LvNVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=y-EDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6026%2C5264195 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |last=Bellamy |first=Ron |title=Is artificial turf safer than grass? |date=September 21, 1989 |page=1B }}</ref><ref name=tfmker>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LXUzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Ce8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2401%2C5323453 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |last=Stalwick |first=Howie |title=Turf maker claims it has the answer |date=November 24, 1984 |page=16}}</ref> It had generally favorable results and installed a second field in 1991, which was used until 2000, when the stadium used Nexturf the next year; it switched again to the current FieldTurf in 2002. [[Martin Stadium]] at [[Washington State University]] in [[Pullman, Washington|Pullman]] switched to Omniturf in 1990,<ref name=fthrec >{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MycuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EdEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5606%2C1888799 |newspaper=Idahonian |location=Moscow |title=For the record |date=May 14, 1990 |page=6A }}</ref> and used it for a decade; like Autzen Stadium, it now uses FieldTurf.
The [[University of Missouri]] in [[Columbia, Missouri|Columbia]] had Omniturf at [[Faurot Field]] from 1985 through 1994, with less favorable reviews.<ref name=afsrfc>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MQNMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oEMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4894%2C319688 |newspaper=Bulletin Journal |location=Cape Girardeau, Missouri |agency=UPI |title=Artificial surface approved for Mizzou |date=May 5, 1985 |page=3B }}</ref><ref name=mzatbtds>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=a7cxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mG4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2500%2C3795363 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |agency=wire dispatches |title=Missouri's artificial turf bites the dust |date=December 20, 1994 |page=C-6 }}</ref> In the early 1990s, the surface was panned by both Tigers and opponents alike as one of the worst in college football.<ref name=scrmsfd>{{cite news |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19941016&slug=1936250 |newspaper=Seattle Times |agency=Associated Press |last=Fallstrom |first=R.B. |title=Missouri ripping up Field Of Screams - treacherous turf faces final weeks of slippery career |date=October 16, 1994 |accessdate=October 30, 2014}}</ref> In 1992, the coaches in the [[Big Eight Conference]] issued a statement that Faurot Field's surface was "a detriment to the home and visiting teams and takes away from the integrity of the game played on such a field."<ref name="mutigers.cstv.com">[http://mutigers.cstv.com/facilities/fac-mem-faurot-fb-timeline.html University of Missouri, Official Athletic Site of the Mizzou Tigers Facilities]</ref> Missouri had a natural grass field prior to 1985, and returned to it in 1995.<ref name=scrmsfd/> The stadium has since switched to a [[FieldTurf]] surface.
==Canada== The only major installation of OmniTurf in Canada was for the [[Canadian Football League|Canadian Football League's]] [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]]'s stadium, [[Mosaic Stadium at Taylor Field|Taylor Field]] in [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]]. It was installed in 1988 and stayed until the end of the 1999 season.<ref>http://www.riderville.com/2002/06/12/history/</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Artificial turf]] [[Category:Queens Park Rangers F.C.]]

/* List of recipients */
revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award | image = Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | subheader = Civilian award for contributions to Sports (Individual/Team) | description = Highest sports honour in India | sponsor = [[Government of India]] | firstawarded = 1991–92 | lastawarded = 2017 | reward = {{INRConvert|7.5|l}} | former name = | holder_label = Most recent winner | holder = {{bulleted list|[[Saikhom Mirabai Chanu]]|[[Virat Kohli]]}} | award1_type = Total awarded | award1_winner = 36 | award2_type = First winner | award2_winner = [[Viswanathan Anand]] | website = | previous = | next = [[Arjuna Award]] }}
The '''Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna''', officially known as '''Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award in Sports and Games''',<ref name="scheme">{{cite web|title=Scheme for the Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award|date=23 February 2015|publisher=Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports|url=http://yas.nic.in/sites/default/files/Rajiv%20Gandhi%20Kel%20Ratna%20Award.pdf|accessdate=2 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160909142048/http://yas.nic.in/sites/default/files/Rajiv%20Gandhi%20Kel%20Ratna%20Award.pdf|archivedate=9 September 2016|df=}}</ref> is the highest sporting honour of the [[India|Republic of India]].<ref name="RGKR15IE">{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/sport-others/sania-mirza-conferred-with-rajiv-gandhi-khel-ratna-award/|title=Sania Mirza conferred with Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna award|date=29 August 2015|accessdate=2 May 2016|newspaper=The Indian Express|location=New Delhi|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001183252/http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/sport-others/sania-mirza-conferred-with-rajiv-gandhi-khel-ratna-award/|archivedate=1 October 2015}}</ref> The award is named after [[Rajiv Gandhi]], former [[Prime Minister of India]] who served the office from 1984 to 1989.<ref name="pm">{{cite web|url=http://pmindia.gov.in/en/former-prime-ministers/|title=Prime Ministers of India|publisher=Prime Minister's Office (India)|accessdate=12 May 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009232119/http://pmindia.gov.in/en/former-prime-ministers/|archivedate=9 October 2014}}</ref> It is awarded annually by the [[Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports]]. The recipient(s) is/are selected by a committee constituted by the Ministry and is honoured for their "spectacular and most outstanding performance in the field of sports over a period of four years" at international level. {{As of|2018}}, the award comprises a [[medal]]lion, a certificate, and a cash prize of {{INRConvert|7.5|l}}.{{efn|The cash prize was revised from {{INRConvert|1|l}} to {{INRConvert|3|l}} in 2000,<ref name="RGKR98"/><ref name="RGKR99"/> to {{INRConvert|5|l}} in 2002,<ref name="RGKR1"/> and to {{INRConvert|7.5|l}} in 2009.<ref name="RGKR9"/>}}<ref name="scheme"/>
Instituted in 1991–1992, the award was given for the performance by a sportsperson in a year. Based on the suggestions provided by 2014 award selection committee, the Ministry revised the criteria in February 2015 to consider the performance over a period of four years. The nominations for a given year are accepted till 30 April or last working day of April with not more than two sportspersons nominated for each sports discipline. A twelve-member committee evaluates the performances of a sportsperson at various International events like [[Olympic Games]], [[Paralympic Games]], [[Asian Games]], and [[Commonwealth Games]]. The committee later submits their recommendations to the [[Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports (India)|Union Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports]] for further approval.
The first recipient of the award was [[Grandmaster (chess)|Chess Grandmaster]] [[Viswanathan Anand]], who was honoured for the performance in the year 1991–92. In 2001, [[Shooting sport|sport shooter]] [[Abhinav Bindra]], then aged 18, became the youngest recipient of the award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiatimes.com/sports/more-sports/abhinav-bindra-5-interesting-facts-about-indias-ace-shooter-175489.html|title=5 Interesting Facts About Abhinav Bindra|work=The Times of India|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=15 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160621122935/http://www.indiatimes.com/sports/more-sports/abhinav-bindra-5-interesting-facts-about-indias-ace-shooter-175489.html|archivedate=21 June 2016|df=}}</ref> Usually conferred upon only one sportsperson in a year, a few exceptions have been made (1993–1994, 2002, 2009, 2012, and 2016–2018) when multiple recipients were awarded in a year. {{As of|2018}}, there have been thirty-six recipients from fourteen sport disciplines: [[Sport of athletics|Athletics]], [[Badminton]], [[English billiards|Billiards]], [[Professional boxing|Boxing]], [[Chess]], [[Cricket]], [[Field hockey]], [[Gymnastics]], [[Shooting sport|Shooting]], [[Snooker]], [[Tennis]], [[Wrestling]], [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]], and [[Yacht racing]]. The most recent recipients of the award are Weightlifter [[Saikhom Mirabai Chanu]] and Cricketer [[Virat Kohli]].
==Nominations==
The nominations for the award are received from all government recognised National Sports Federations, the [[Indian Olympic Association]], the [[Sports Authority of India]] (SAI), the Sports Promotion and Control Boards, and the state and the union territory governments with not more than two eligible sportspersons nominated for each sports discipline. In case of cricket, the nominations are received from the [[Board of Control for Cricket in India]] and SAI is authorised to submit the nominations on behalf of all the de-recognised or under suspension National Sports Federations.{{efn|name=cricket|For cricket, there is no National Sports Federation recognised by the Government.<ref name="scheme"/>}} The previous award recipients can also nominate one sportsperson for the discipline for which they themselves were awarded. The Government can nominate up to two sportspersons in deserving cases where no such nominations have been received from the nominating authorities. The nominations for a given year are accepted till 30 April or last working day of April.<ref name="scheme"/>
==Selection process==
All the received nominations are sent to SAI and [[National Anti-Doping Agency]] for the verification against the claimed achievements and doping clearance respectively. Any sportsperson who is either penalised or being enquired for usage of drugs or substances banned by the [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] is not eligible for the award. A committee consisting of the Joint Secretary and the Director/Deputy Secretary of Department of Sports, the Secretary and the Executive Director/Director (TEAMS) of SAI verify and validate the nominations.<ref name="scheme"/>
The valid nominations are placed before the selection committee constituted by the Government. This twelve member committee consists of a Chairperson nominated by the Ministry, four Olympians or previous recipients of Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna or [[Arjuna Award]], three sports journalists/experts/commentators, one sportsperson/expert/administrator associated with [[Disabled sports|parasports]], one sports administrator, the Director General of SAI, and the Joint Secretary of Department of Sports, with not more than one sportsperson from a particular discipline included in the committee.<ref name="scheme"/> When instituted in 1991–92, the award was given for the performance by a sportsperson in a year.<ref name="RGKR98"/><ref>{{cite press_release|title=Criteria for Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award, Dronacharya Award and Dhyan chand Award|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=102969|publisher=Press Information Bureau, India|accessdate=3 May 2016|date=3 February 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602020854/http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=102969|archivedate=2 June 2016|df=}}</ref> Based on the suggestions provided by 2014 award selection committee headed by [[Kapil Dev]],<ref name="RGKR14"/><ref>{{cite press_release|title=National Sports Awards Schemes Revamped|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=115679|publisher=Press Information Bureau, India|accessdate=3 May 2016|date=23 February 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602020857/http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=115679|archivedate=2 June 2016|df=}}</ref> the Ministry revised the criteria in February 2015 to consider the performance over a period of four years.<ref>{{cite press_release|title=Committee for National Awards|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/mbErel.aspx?relid=118438|publisher=Press Information Bureau, India|accessdate=3 May 2016|date=21 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602020431/http://pib.nic.in/newsite/mbErel.aspx?relid=118438|archivedate=2 June 2016|df=}}</ref>
The medals won in various International championships and events of the disciplines which include Summer and Winter Olympic and Paralympics Games, Asian Games, and Commonwealth Games are given 80% weightage. The remaining 20% weightage is given to the profile and standard of the events. For any other games not included in Olympic, Asian Games, and Commonwealth Games like cricket and indigenous games, the individuals performance of a sportsperson is taken into consideration. The sportsperson with maximum points is given 80 marks. Rest of the sportspersons are given marks in proportion to the maximum points. For team events, marks are given as per the strength of the team.<ref name="scheme"/> Following are the points defined for medals at the given events:
{| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;width:60%" |+Points for winning medals for the performance during the last four years |- ! scope="col" rowspan="2" | Event ! scope="col" colspan="3" | Medal |- ! scope="col" | {{Gold medal}} ! scope="col" | {{Silver medal}} ! scope="col" | {{Bronze medal}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Olympic Games]]/[[Paralympic Games]] | 80 || 70 || 55 |- ! scope="row" | [[World championship|World Championship]]/[[World cup competition|World Cup]]{{efn|A World Championship/World Cup is generally organised every four years. For different cyclicities, proportionate marks are given.}} | 40 || 30 || 20 |- ! scope="row" | [[Asian Games]] | 30 || 25 || 20 |- ! scope="row" | [[Commonwealth Games]] | 25 || 20 || 15 |}
For a given discipline, not more than two sportspersons, one male and one female, are given highest marks. The committee may not recommend the award to the sportsperson with the highest marks across disciplines but can only recommend the recipient of the highest aggregate marks in a particular sports discipline. The recommendations of the selection committee are submitted to the [[Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports (India)|Union Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports]] for further approval.<ref name="scheme"/>
==List of recipients==
{| class="wikitable" |+ Key |- |align=center style="width:50px;background-color:#CEE8F0"|# |Indicates a joint award for the given year |}
[[File:London Chess Classic 2010 Anand 04.jpg|alt=A photograph of a man playing Chess with blue sweater.|thumbnail|upright|The first recipient of the award [[Viswanathan Anand]] is country's first chess [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] and a five time winner of [[World Chess Championship]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.ndtv.com/chess/news/217314-who-is-viswanathan-anand|title=Why is Viswanathan Anand a chess legend?|date=22 November 2013|accessdate=15 November 2015|publisher=NDTVSports|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117032620/http://sports.ndtv.com/chess/news/217314-who-is-viswanathan-anand|archivedate=17 November 2015|df=}}</ref>]]
[[File:Pankaj Advani PHC 2012-1.jpg|alt=A photograph of a man playing Snooker wearing white shirt and black waistcoat.|thumbnail|upright|[[Pankaj Advani]] is the only sportsperson to have won the award for two sports disciplines; Billiards and Snooker.]]
