==Controversies==
The 2002 selection committee headed by former football player [[Pradip Kumar Banerjee]] made twenty one recommendations for the [[Arjuna Award]] and two recommendations for the Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award, athlete [[K. M. Beenamol]] and shooter [[Anjali Bhagwat]]. The government rejected the recommendations and asked the committee to cut down the list to comply with the award guidelines, where only one sportsperson for the Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award and fifteen sportspersons along with one disabled athlete for the Arjuna Awards could be recommended each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Arjuna-Awards-panel-to-prune-list/articleshow/118763.cms|title=Arjuna Awards panel to prune list|work=The Times of India|date=7 August 2003|agency=Press Trust of India|accessdate=14 May 2016|location=New Delhi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803124633/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Arjuna-Awards-panel-to-prune-list/articleshow/118763.cms|archivedate=3 August 2016|df=}}</ref> The committee revised the list to recommend Beenamol for the award over Bhagwat but also put a request "to consider everyone".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/2003/aug/09khel.htm|title=Beenamol to get Khel Ratna|publisher=Rediff.com|date=9 August 2003|accessdate=15 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805012504/http://www.rediff.com/sports/2003/aug/09khel.htm|archivedate=5 August 2016|df=}} * {{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2003/08/23/stories/2003082307431700.htm|title=Beenamol, Anjali to share Khel Ratna|date=23 August 2003|accessdate=15 May 2016|newspaper=The Hindu|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180203083511/http://www.thehindu.com/2003/08/23/stories/2003082307431700.htm|archivedate=3 February 2018|df=}}</ref> The decision spurred criticism for ignoring the achievements of the shooter and Bhagwat and the [[National Rifle Association of India]] expressed their "disappointment" with the decision.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/2003/08/10/stories/2003081004591700.htm|title=Beenamol to get Khel Ratna|date=10 August 2003|accessdate=15 May 2016|newspaper=The Hindu|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180203083511/http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/2003/08/10/stories/2003081004591700.htm|archivedate=3 February 2018|df=}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2003/20030811/sports.htm#2|title=Anjali flays awards panel|newspaper=The Tribune|date=10 August 2003|accessdate=15 May 2016|location=New Delhi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150127192526/http://www.tribuneindia.com/2003/20030811/sports.htm#2|archivedate=27 January 2015|df=}} * {{cite news|url=http://expressindia.indianexpress.com/news/fullstory.php?newsid=23807|title=Sidelined, shooter Anjali Bhagwat slams Arjuna award selection|date=10 August 2003|work=Press Trust of India|publisher=The Indian Express|accessdate=15 May 2016|author=Srivastava, Abhaya|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160806144311/http://expressindia.indianexpress.com/news/fullstory.php?newsid=23807|archivedate=6 August 2016|df=}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/2003/aug/10anjali.htm|title=Anjali slams Arjuna Awards committee|publisher=Rediff.com|date=10 August 2003|accessdate=15 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805012507/http://www.rediff.com/sports/2003/aug/10anjali.htm|archivedate=5 August 2016|df=}}</ref> Later, the government accepted all the recommendations "as an exception" and jointly awarded Beenamol and Bhagwat for the year 2002.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1030830/asp/sports/story_2315737.asp|title=33 sportspersons honoured: Controversy set aside as stars get their due from the President|date=30 August 2003|accessdate=15 May 2016|newspaper=The Telegraph|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610152120/http://www.telegraphindia.com/1030830/asp/sports/story_2315737.asp|archivedate=10 June 2016|df=}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/2003/aug/22awards.htm|title=Anjali, Beenamol get Khel Ratna|publisher=Rediff.com|date=22 August 2003|accessdate=15 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805012510/http://www.rediff.com/sports/2003/aug/22awards.htm|archivedate=5 August 2016|df=}}</ref>
In August 2013, the selection committee headed by [[Michael Ferreira]] recommended [[Shooting sport|sport shooter]] [[Ronjan Sodhi]] for the award, with some committee members questioning the process of selection.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/ronjan-sodhi-khel-ratna-irks-krishna-poonia-improper-selection-sports-panel-politics-ace-shooter/1/299466.html|title=Ronjan Sodhi's Khel Ratna nomination irks Krishna Poonia|publisher=''India Today''|date=14 August 2013|accessdate=15 May 2016|location=New Delhi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604071422/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/ronjan-sodhi-khel-ratna-irks-krishna-poonia-improper-selection-sports-panel-politics-ace-shooter/1/299466.html|archivedate=4 June 2016|df=}}</ref> A committee member noted that [[discus throw]]er [[Krishna Poonia]], and Paralympic athlete [[Girisha Nagarajegowda|H. N. Girisha]] were shortlisted and Sodhi was not the initial choice. However, Girisha's name was removed, and the final voting was done between Sodhi and Poonia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.ndtv.com/athletics/news/212730-khel-ratna-controversy-krishna-poonia-hits-back-at-anjali-bhagwat-says-didnt-lobby-for-award|title=Khel Ratna controversy: Krishna Poonia hits back at Anjali Bhagwat; says didn't lobby for award|publisher=NDTV|date=21 August 2013|agency=Press Trust of India|accessdate=14 May 2016|location=New Delhi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160605115318/http://sports.ndtv.com/athletics/news/212730-khel-ratna-controversy-krishna-poonia-hits-back-at-anjali-bhagwat-says-didnt-lobby-for-award|archivedate=5 June 2016|df=}}</ref> Poonia was accused of lobbying for the award by one of the committee member Anjali Bhagwat,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/new-twist-in-khel-ratna-controversy--anjali-bhagwat-claims-poonia-lobbied-with-her/227965|title=New twist in Khel Ratna controversy: Anjali Bhagwat claims Poonia lobbied with her|newspaper=Mid-Day|agency=Press Trust of India|date=21 August 2013|accessdate=15 May 2016|location=New Delhi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530150858/http://www.mid-day.com/articles/new-twist-in-khel-ratna-controversy--anjali-bhagwat-claims-poonia-lobbied-with-her/227965|archivedate=30 May 2016|df=}}</ref> but the accused met the then Union Sports Minister [[Jitendra Singh (Congress politician)|Jitendra Singh]] to promote her case and also rubbished the lobbying allegations.<ref name="RGKR13Sportstar">{{cite journal|url=http://www.sportstaronnet.com/tss3636/stories/20130907507105900.htm|title=Awards and the controversy thereafter|journal=Sportstar|volume=36|issue=36|date=2013|accessdate=15 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/krishna-poonia-on-khel-ratna-controversy/1/300629.html|title=Didn't lobby for award: Krishna Poonia on Khel Ratna controversy|publisher=''India Today''|date=21 August 2013|accessdate=15 May 2016|location=New Delhi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604065408/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/krishna-poonia-on-khel-ratna-controversy/1/300629.html|archivedate=4 June 2016|df=}}</ref> The Ministry conducted a separate enquiry by Secretary of Department of Sports and decided not to increase the number of awards "to maintain the stature of the awards".<ref name="RGKR13Sportstar"/>
Following an announcement, in August 2015, that tennis player [[Sania Mirza]] was to be awarded, a [[Public interest law|Public-Interest Litigation]] was filed in the [[Karnataka High Court]]. The petitioner, Paralympic athlete H. N. Girisha, mentioned that his performance was ignored by the committee.<ref name="RGKR15DNA">{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/report-karnataka-hc-stays-sania-mirza-s-rajiv-gandhi-khel-ratna-award-2118745|title=Karnataka HC stays Sania Mirza's Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna award|date=26 August 2015|accessdate=6 May 2016|location=Mumbai|newspaper=Daily News and Analysis|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150829224802/http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/report-karnataka-hc-stays-sania-mirza-s-rajiv-gandhi-khel-ratna-award-2118745|archivedate=29 August 2015|df=}}</ref> Girisha claimed to be a top contender for the award with 90 points, owing to his silver medal winning act at the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] in the [[Athletics at the 2012 Summer Paralympics – Men's high jump|Men's High Jump F42 event]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.ndtv.com/athletics/news/196056-girisha-hosanagara-nagarajegowda-bags-first-paralympic-medal-for-india|title=Girisha Hosanagara Nagarajegowda bags first Paralympic medal for India|publisher=NDTV|date=4 September 2012|agency=Press Trust of India|accessdate=14 May 2016|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160605101648/http://sports.ndtv.com/athletics/news/196056-girisha-hosanagara-nagarajegowda-bags-first-paralympic-medal-for-india|archivedate=5 June 2016|df=}}</ref> The petition mentioned that the points for Mirza's [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] titles from 2011 until 2015 should not be counted as the events were not a part of the list of sports events to be considered for the performance evaluation.{{efn|Mirza has won [[2012 French Open – Mixed Doubles]] with [[Mahesh Bhupathi]], [[2014 US Open – Mixed Doubles]] with [[Bruno Soares]], and [[2015 US Open – Women's Doubles]] and [[2015 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Doubles]] with [[Martina Hingis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtatennis.com/players/player/9471/title/sania-mirza#careerhighlights|title=Sania Mirza profile|publisher=Women's Tennis Association|accessdate=14 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160519213458/http://www.wtatennis.com/players/player/9471/title/sania-mirza#careerhighlights|archivedate=19 May 2016|df=}}</ref>}} The court withheld the conferment and sought replies from the Ministry about the selection process. The Ministry nevertheless presented the award to Mirza on 29 August 2015 amidst the case processing.<ref name="RGKR15IE"/>

revision.comment: added [[Category:Water sports equipment]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Oarlock (PSF).png|thumb|right|A rowlock on a rowing boat]] [[Image:Rowing Sport Oarlock.jpg|thumb|right|A rowlock used for the sport of rowing]]
A '''rowlock'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/rowlock|title=rowlock Meaning in the Cambridge English Dictionary|publisher=|accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref> {{IPAc-en|uk|ˈ|r|ɒ|l|ə|k}}, sometimes '''spur''' (due to the similarity in shape and size), '''oarlock''' (USA)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vocabularie.com/oarlock|title=Oarlock - definition and common misspellings|publisher=|accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref> or '''gate''' (Australia) is a brace that attaches an [[oar]] to a [[rowing|boat]]. When a boat is rowed, the rowlock acts as a [[lever|fulcrum]], and, in doing so, the propulsive force that the rower exerts on the water with the oar is transferred to the boat by the thrust force exerted on the rowlock.
On ordinary rowing craft, the rowlocks are attached to the [[gunwale]]s. In the sport of [[rowing (sport)|rowing]], the rowlocks are attached to [[outrigger]]s (often just called "riggers"), which project from the boat and provide greater leverage. In sport rowing, the rowlocks are normally U-shaped and attached to a vertical pin which allows the rowlock to pivot around the pin during the rowing stroke. They additionally have a locking mechanism (properly known as "the gate") across the top of the "U" to prevent the oar from unintentionally popping out of the rowlock.
Originally, rowlocks were two wooden posts or [[Glossary of nautical terms#Thole|thole]] pins that the shaft of the oar nestled between. Single THOLE PINS may be used when the oars have holes cut into the loom which then sits over/around the THOLE PIN. (Captain Dennis Robinson FNI, Master Mariner)
==Sport rowing== In sport rowing oarlocks were originally brass or bronze and open (no gate). With the advent of modern materials oarlocks are now injection moulded plastic and precision made to minimize play (slop) between the oar collar and the oarlock. The most recent sport racing oarlocks have a spring loaded feature to keeps the oar collar firmly against the pin at all times.
Oarlocks are technical pieces of equipment in sport rowing, holding the oar shaft and therefore the oar blade at the correct angle in the water to ensure optimum performance.
==Heraldry==
The Norwegian municipalities of [[Fosnes]], [[Radøy]] and [[Tjøme]] have rowlocks in their coats-of-arms.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Rowing]] [[Category:Water sports equipment]]

revision.text:
[[File:Map-Six-and-Ten-Day-Race.jpg|thumb|right|Map]] The '''Self-Transcendence 6- & 10- day''' race are two concurrently [[multiday races|multiday]] running events at the [[Flushing Meadows – Corona Park|Corona Park]], borough [[Queens]] in [[New York City]].{{coord|40.739425|-73.843132|type:event_globe:earth_region:US-AK_scale:2000|name="Self-Transcendence 6- & 10-day Race"|display=title}} The course is one mile (1.6  km) long.<ref name="HB" /> They are held annually in April and organized by the [[Chinmoy|Sri Chinmoy]] Marathon Team.<ref name="md" /><ref name="scr" /><ref name="duv" />
==History and Records== The Team held a 1000-mile race in the spring of 1985, and later in the year held the first [[Sri Chinmoy]] Five Day Race at [[Flushing Meadow Park]] in [[Queens]], which lasted for three consecutive years and led to the Seven Day Race, the forerunner of today's Ten Day event. The first Five Day Race featured 15 competitors as did the first Seven Day Race. By 1995 the longer event grew to 34 starters.
In the inaugural Seven Day Race in 1988, Marty Sprengelmeyer of Davenport, Iowa narrowly beat women's winner [[Suprabha Beckjord]] of Washington, DC. 527 miles to 521 miles.
In 1990 ultra legend [[Al Howie]] set a new record of 530 miles. The following year Charlie Eidel of Gardiner, NY ran 550 miles for a new course record, while Suprabha Beckjord ran 523 to claim the women's record again. Suprabha won the Seven Day five times for the ladies. In 1994 Antana Locs of Canada won the Seven Day overall with 518 miles. Georgs Jermolajevs came all the way from Latvia to win the Seven Day Race in 1995, in record-setting fashion, running 578 miles, while England's Pippa Davis finally laid claim to the women's title as she ran 525 miles. In the 1996 inaugural Ten Day Race, Georgs Jermolajevs again fashioned a victory with 725 miles, but was hard pressed by [[Dipali Cunningham]] of Australia, who garnered 723 miles for the ladies. In a smaller field in 1997 veteran Donald Winkley of Corpus Christi,Texas prevailed with 530 miles.
In 1998 the [[Sri Chinmoy]] Marathon Team added the 6 day race to their calendar in this year Dipali Cunningham breaking [[Sandy Barwick]]'s record with 504 miles. In 2000 [[Ted Corbitt]] at 81 set a new World age-group best (80-84) with 240 miles and in the following year, 2001, the last races held at Wards Island yielded another great performance from Dipali Cunningham - winning the 6 day overall and set a new World Record with 510 miles.<ref name="md" /><ref name="scr" /><ref name="duv" /><ref name="inspiringnews" />
==See also== * [[Self-Transcendence 3100 Mile Race]]

{{Infobox football club |clubname=T. I. and Power |image= |fullname=T. I. and Power Football Club |nickname= |founded= |ground=[[Changlimithang Stadium|Changlimithang]]
[[Thimpu]], [[Bhutan]] |capacity=15,000 |chairman= |manager= |coach= |league=[[A-Division (Bhutan)|Bhutan A-Division]] |season=[[1986 A-Division (Bhutan)|1986]] |position=8th{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bhutan86.html|title=Bhutan 1986|last=Burns|first=Peter|last2=Makdissi|first2=Albert| date=31 July 2003| website=www.rsssf.com|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}} | }} '''T. I. and Power''' was a football club from [[Bhutan]], based at [[Changlimithang Stadium|Changlimithang]], who played in the inaugural [[A-Division (Bhutan)|Bhutan A-Division]], then the top level of football in Bhutan, but since replaced by a full [[Bhutan National League|national league]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bhutan2012.html|title=Bhutan 2012|last=Schöggl|first=Hans|last2=Stokkermans|first2=Karel|last3=Jigmi|first3=Sonam|date=28 Feb 2013|website=www.rsssf.com|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}} ==History== They finished eighth in the [[1986 A-Division (Bhutan)|inaugural]] season, with just a single victory over [[Health School]] and two draws against [[Public Works Department (Bhutanese football club)|Public Works Department]] and [[Education (Bhutanese football club)|Education]] to their name. They scored eleven goals in the whole competition, more than any other team outside the top three, but were defensively the weakest in the league, conceding twenty goals in total. There are no records available for any competitions held between 1987–1995{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bhutanchamp.html|title=Bhutan – List of Champions|last=Schöggl|first=Hans|last2=Abbink|first2=Dinant|date=28 May 2014|website=www.rsssf.com|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}} so it is not known whether they competed again, and there is no record of them competing in any future season for which records exist. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Thimphu League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Bhutan]] [[Category:Sport in Thimphu]] {{Bhutan-footyclub-stub}}

revision.comment: add reference to the bat being officially called a racket
revision.text:
[[Image:Tabletennis.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Table tennis racqet]] A basic '''table tennis racqet''' (also known as a "[[bat-and-ball games|paddle]]" or "bat") is used by [[table tennis]] players. The table tennis racket is usually made from laminated wood covered with rubber on one or two sides depending on the player's grip. Unlike a conventional "[[Racqet_(sports_equipment)|racqet]]", it does not include strings strung across an open frame. The USA generally uses the term "paddle" while Europeans and Asians use the term "bat" and the official ITTF term is "racket".<ref>{{cite book |author=ITTF |date=August 2018 |accessdate=16 November 2018 |title=The International Table Tennis Federation Handbook 2018 |url=https://d3mjm6zw6cr45s.cloudfront.net/2018/02/2018ITTFHandbook_v2.pdf_0.pdf}}</ref>
== Various == {{multiple image | width = 200 | footer = One side must be red and the other black | footer_align = center | image1 = Shakehand1.jpg | alt1 = Red side of the paddle | image2 = Shakehand2.jpg | alt2 = Black side of the paddle }} Table tennis regulations approved by the [[International Table Tennis Federation]] (ITTF) allow different surfaces on each side of the paddle for various amounts of spin (including nullifying it) or speed.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Varenberg|first1=M.|last2=Varenberg|first2=A.|date=2012|title=Table tennis rubber: Tribological characterization|journal=Tribology Letters|volume=47|issue=1|pages=51–56|doi=10.1007/s11249-012-9961-4|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11249-012-9961-4}}</ref> For example, a player may have a spin-heavy rubber on one side of his paddle, and no spin on the other side. The player can flip the racket in play for different types of returns. To help a player distinguish between different types of rubber used by his opponent, regulations specify that one side of a paddle must be red while the other must be black, allowing a player to see what side of a paddle hits the ball mid-play. The player has the right to inspect his opponent's racquet before a match to see the type and color. Current rules state that, unless damaged in play, the paddle cannot be exchanged for another at any time during a match.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ping Pong Paddle|url=https://bestreviewshunt.com/best-ping-pong-paddle/|publisher=Bestreviewshunt.com|accessdate=17 November 2016|date=11 October 2016}}</ref>
The rubber coating may be of pimpled rubber, with the pimples outward, or it may be composed of a sponge layer, covered by rubber that may have the pimples pointed inwards or outwards. Some paddles are not covered with rubber ("naked") to make it spin resistant. However, it is illegal to use these types of racquet in competition as they are not approved by the ITTF. Some types of rubbers are also not approved. Approved rubbers have the ITTF emblem on the base of the rubber.<ref>{{cite web|title=Table tennis|url=http://www.sizes.com/sports/table_tennis.htm#website|website=www.sizes.com|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref>
== Assembling == ;Choices Players have many choices and variations in rubber sheets on their racquet. Although a racquet may be purchased assembled with rubber by the manufacturer, most serious tournament players will use a custom racquet. A player selects a blank blade (i.e., a racquet without rubber) based on his or her playing style. The type of wood or synthetic layers used to make up the blade will determine the blade's speed. The different types of rubber sheets affect the level of spin, speed, and other specific playing characteristics. Racquet construction and new rubber technology contribute significantly to the amount of deviation from the expected ball flight path.
==Glue and gluing== Normally, a sheet of rubber is glued to a blade using various table tennis brand glues such as Butterfly, Donic, and DHS. Some glues may work even if it wasn't designed specifically for table tennis, such as Rubber Cement and Tear Mender. The rubber is not removed until it wears out or becomes damaged. In the 1980s, some players developed a new technique with a special glue called [[speed glue]] to apply the rubber every time he played. The glue would help provide more spin and speed by providing a "[[catapult]]" effect.
The fairly recent development of speed glue speeds up the departure of the ball from the rubber considerably, though at the cost of some ball control on [[touch shot]]s <!-- Note: This seems to be a table tennis term, so please don't change it to "tough" which is what I thought it should be until I Googled the term. --> where little or no spin is put on the ball. Speed glue was allowed for the last time in the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. From the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] onward, the Olympic games banned speed glue.<ref>[http://tabletennis.about.com/od/speedglue/a/ban_speedglue.htm ITTF Bans Speed Glue, Boosters and Tuners - and Much More!] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402105148/http://tabletennis.about.com/od/speedglue/a/ban_speedglue.htm |date=2015-04-02 }} By Greg Letts, About.com. Accessed September 2008</ref>
== Maintaining and protection == The surface of a racquet will develop a smooth glossy [[patina]] with use. The rubber surface needs regular cleaning to retain a high friction surface for ball spin. Commercial cleaners or water and soap can be cleaning agents.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.megaspin.net/info/equip.asp|title= Table Tennis Information - Equipment maintenance|accessdate=2007-07-10 |last=|first=|authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |year= |month= |format= |work= |publisher=Megaspin |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref>
Sun exposure may damage the rubber.
==See also== * [[Table tennis]]
==References== {{Commonscat|Table tennis bat}} {{reflist}}
[[Category:Table tennis|*]] [[Category:Sports equipment]]

{{Infobox football biography | name = Timothy Cathalina | image = | caption = | fullname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1985|1|24|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Willemstad]], [[Curaçao]],
[[Netherlands Antilles]] | height = {{height|m=1.81}} | position = [[Defender (association football)|Right back]] | currentclub = [[SV Spakenburg]] | clubnumber = 25 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[FC Twente]] | years1 = 2005–2009 | clubs1 = [[AGOVV Apeldoorn|AGOVV]] | caps1 = 111 | goals1 = 5 | years2 = 2009–2010 | clubs2 = [[FC Emmen]] | caps2 = 18 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2010–2011 | clubs3 = [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] | caps3 = 7 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2011– | clubs4 = [[SV Spakenburg|Spakenburg]] | caps4 = 0 | goals4 = 0 | club-update = 18:21, 3 January 2011 (UTC) }} '''Timothy Cathalina''' (born 24 January 1985) is a professional [[association football|footballer]] from [[Curaçao]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|right back]] for [[SV Spakenburg]].{{cite web|url=http://www.topklasser.nl/transfers|title=Ontbreken er transfers? Tip ons!|accessdate=5 August 2011|date=5 August 2011|publisher=[[Topklasse]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110729183454/http://www.topklasser.nl/transfers#|archive-date=2011-07-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} ==Career== Born in [[Willemstad]], [[Curaçao]], in the former [[Netherlands Antilles]], Cathalina played youth football with [[FC Twente]] but began his professional career in 2005 with [[AGOVV Apeldoorn]], making over 100 appearances, before moving to [[FC Emmen]] in 2009. On 27 January 2010, Cathalina played on trial for [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] in a behind-closed-doors friendly against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] at [[Blundell Park]].{{cite web|url=http://www.grimsby-townfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10417~1945234,00.html|title=Town Beaten By Tigers|accessdate=4 June 2010|date=27 January 2010|publisher=Grimsby Town F.C. official website|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322131015/http://www.grimsby-townfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10417~1945234,00.html|archivedate=22 March 2012|df=}} On 4 June 2010, Cathalina signed a one-year deal with [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] following a two-week trial towards the end of the 2009–10 season.{{cite web|url=http://www.tranmererovers.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10365~2064855,00.html|title=Dutch Antillean Signs For Rovers|accessdate=4 June 2010|date=4 June 2010|publisher=Tranmere Rovers F.C. official website}} In April 2011 his contract was cancelled by the club through mutual consent to allow him to look for an alternative club before the summer break.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13097590.stm?|title=Tranmere Rovers cancel Tim Cathalina contract|accessdate=15 April 2011|date=15 April 2011|publisher=BBC Sport}} In July 2011 announced his return to Netherlands and signed with [[SV Spakenburg]].{{cite web|url=http://topklasse.com/topklasse-timothy-cathalina-tekent-contract-bij-spakenburg.html|title=Timothy Cathalina tekent contract bij Spakenburg|accessdate=26 July 2011|date=5 August 2011|publisher=[[Topklasse]]}} ==References== ;General *{{nl icon}} [http://www.vi.nl/Spelers/Speler/TimothyCathalina.htm Voetbal revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{ infobox stadium | name = Tipsport arena | nickname = | logo_image = [[Image:Tipsport Arena.svg|210px]] | image = Praha T-Mobile Arena (6).JPG | image_size = 250px | fullname = | location = Za elektrárnou 419/1 170 00 [[Prague]] 7-Bubeneč, [[Czech Republic]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1952 | built = 1962 | opened = 7 March 1962 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Sportovní hala (1962–1999)
Paegas Arena (1999–2002)
T-Mobile Arena (2002–2008)
Tesla Arena (2008–2011)
Tipsport Arena (2011–present) | tenants = [[HC Sparta Praha]] (1962–2015)
[[HC Lev Praha]] ([[Kontinental Hockey League|KHL]]) (2012–2014) | capacity = [[Ice hockey]]: 13,150[http://www.hcsparta.cz/zobraz.asp?t=info-o-arene] | dimensions = 29 x 60 m | scoreboard = }} '''Tipsport Arena''' is a multi-purpose [[arena]] in Prague, Czech Republic, whose naming rights are currently leased to Czech betting company [[Tipsport]]. The arena, located on the fairgrounds in the neighbourhood of [[Holešovice]], opened in 1962 as '''Sportovní hala''' and has a capacity of 13,150 for [[ice hockey]] games. It was the home arena of Czech extraliga team [[HC Sparta Praha]] and KHL's [[HC Lev Praha]]. During its existence, the arena has hosted many important sporting events. It hosted the [[Ice Hockey World Championships]] four times and for years hosted a prestigious annual figure skating competition. The arena hosted the [[1980 Davis Cup]] final, where [[Czechoslovakia Davis Cup team|Czechoslovakia]] defeated [[Italy Davis Cup team|Italy]]. Hundreds of concerts have also been staged at the arena during its history. It was the largest and most important arena in Czechoslovakia and the Czech Republic for over 40 years until the new [[O2 Arena (Prague)|O2 Arena]] opened in 2004. ==Development of the name== *1962-99: Sportovní hala *1999-2002: Paegas Arena *2002-08: T-Mobile Arena *2008-11: Tesla Arena *2011–present: '''Tipsport arena''' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Tesla Arena}} *[http://tipsportarena-praha.cz/?lang=cs Official Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070323102240/http://hcsparta.cz/arena.asp HC Sparta Praha] *[http://www.czecot.com/en/results/kongresy-info.php?id=1473 Detailed description of Tesla Arena with map and photos] *[http://www.hcsparta.cz/foto/arena/planek_haly/planek_haly.jpg The plan of the Tesla Arena] * {{coord|50.10705|N|14.433653|E|region:CZ_type:landmark|display=title}} {{KHL Arenas}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[European Indoor Championships in Athletics|European Indoor Games]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2015}} '''Touch match officials''' are responsible for fairly enforcing the ''Playing Rules'' of [[Touch (sport)|Touch]] during a match and imposing penalties for deliberate breaches of these rules.{{cite web|title=Playing Rules, 4th Edition|url=http://www.sportingpulse.com/assoc_page.cgi?client=14-4863-0-0-0&sID=64321&&news_task=DETAIL&articleID=5215330|publisher=Federation of International Touch|accessdate=31 January 2013}} The most senior match official is the ''referee'', they may be assisted by a range of other officials depending on the level and rules of the competition. ==Equipment== The match officials may use the following equipment: ;Coin :The referee organises a coin toss with the team captains to decide who taps off and what end each team takes initially. ;Whistle :Referees must carry a [[whistle]] to stop play and then signal to players about many things during a game. A referee will let players know when to stop after foul play or while awarding a [[Touch football (rugby league)#Scoring|touchdown]] and at other times in a game. ==Uniform== All referees wear an official uniform of a colour (generally white) distinguishable from those being worn by the two sides playing each other. Referees wear a coloured badge to indicate which [[#Levels|level of accreditation]] they have achieved.{{cite web|title=International Uniform Policy|url=http://www.sportingpulse.com/assoc_page.cgi?client=14-4863-0-0-0&sID=64321&&news_task=DETAIL&articleID=14391191|publisher=Federation of International Touch|accessdate=31 January 2013|location=7|page=2}} ==Accreditation== Referees must first pass refereeing exams set by their national governing body before officiating at progressively more senior levels of the sport, gaining experience in lower-level competitions and then moving onto higher-level competitions where they will progress to the top if good enough. ===Levels=== Referees are accredited according to a numbered level system, with '''Level 1''' generally being the lowest, introductory, level. The number of levels as well as badge colours, shapes and sizes differ depending on the governing body.
''[[Touch Football Australia]] operates under a six-level structure{{cite web|title=Section 2|url=http://www.sportingpulse.com/assoc_page.cgi?client=14-3591-0-0-0&sID=46574&&news_task=DETAIL&articleID=4247529|work=Referees Policy & Procedures Manual|publisher=Touch Football Australia|accessdate=31 January 2013}} while [[Touch NZ]] uses a four-level system and [[Touch Europe]] uses five.'' ====Gold Badge==== The '''Gold Badge''' is the most distinguished badge that can be awarded to a referee and is awarded by the [[Federation of International Touch]]. At present, they are awarded to the ten highest ranked referees at the [[Touch Football World Cup]], which is held every four years.{{cite web|title=touchnz.co.nz/index.php?id=16&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=238&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=17&cHash=a2c6b65e2a|url=http://www.touchnz.co.nz/index.php?id=16&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=238&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=17&cHash=a2c6b65e2a|publisher=Touch NZ|accessdate=31 January 2013}} ==Refereeing systems== Different refereeing systems are in use: ;'''Single Referee''' :One referee officiates the match, without the help of sideline officials. The single-referee system is usually only used in park-level/social competition where the availability of referees is low. ;'''Dual Referee''' :Two referees control the match and alternate between the role of central referee and sideline official. The dual-referee system is used only in park-level/social competition where the availability of referees is low. ;'''Triple Referee''' :Three referees control the match in a similar way to the dual-referee system, with one central referee and a sideline official on each sideline. The triple-referee system is the standard system and is required at all representative levels of the game. ==Positions and responsibilities== ===Player safety=== Referees are to inspect player uniforms, playing boots, jewellery and fingernails to ensure player safety. ===Tap-off and direction=== The referees organises a coin toss with the captains of the two teams playing to decide which team taps off and which end they play at from tap-off. ===Area of control=== Referees have control over all players and team officials participating in the match, including substitute players. A referee's area of control extends to a general radius of 10 metres from the edge of the field. ===Referee's signals=== The referee uses signals to communicate his/her decisions with the players, team officials and spectators. ===Central Referee and Sideline Officials=== Generally, matches are controlled by three referees, alternating between the role of central referee and sideline official. The central referee controls play and makes all decisions. Sideline officials are responsible for controlling substituting players, advising the referee of forward passes (through discreet signals), and assisting the central referee in controlling onside defenders. Only the central referee uses his/her whistle. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Touch Football Match Officials}} [[Category:Sports officiating]] [[Category:Touch (sport)]]

revision.text:
{{about|the ball thrown on water|the large inflatable sphere|Water ball|the Water Balz expanding toy|Expandable water toy}} {{more citations needed|date=April 2011}} [[Image:Brother & sister 1 mile- 1.jpg|thumb|250px|alt=People playing with a waterball.|People playing with a waterball.]]
'''Waterballs''' are water toys that are played on the water surface with players interacting with the water toy and the water in any number of play patterns. Generally players throw waterballs at varying speeds across the water and air at varying angles to get the desired [[Stone skipping|skip]] pattern. Play is generally between players and play patterns can involve a variety of apparatus and equipment, such as special pools with goals and watercourts.
==In popular culture== They are palm-sized waterballs that can travel as fast as they can be thrown. They can travel a great distance, even crossing large moving [[waterways]]. High-performance waterballs currently are not well known to the public as they have only been on the US market for a few years, having been introduced in the summer of 2008 with the launch of the [[Waboba|Waboba Ball]].<ref name=telegraphball>{{Cite web|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/2484555/Ball-that-bounces-on-water-is-latest-beach-toy.html|title = Ball that bounces on water is summer craze|date = 2008-08-01|website = Telegraph.co.uk|access-date = 2016-05-14}}</ref>
Splash balls or [[Water balloon|water bombs]] are well known to the public and have been on the market in the US for years. They are designed for children and adults to play on a water surface. These are also more suitable for children and non-sport uses. Splash balls or [[Water balloon|water bombs]] are not high-performance waterballs or part of this discussion.
There are a number of [[nerf]]-styled [[Water polo|polo]] waterballs on the market that are smaller and softer than the regulation sport polo waterball. These are also more suitable for children and non-sport uses. These are polo and catch balls designed to play on the water surface however they are not high-performance waterballs or part of this discussion.
Generally, high-performance waterballs have little [[friction]] on the water, they are relatively small in size and density making them generally a [[handball]] size. With a certain amount of force they skip, bounce and glide in a straight line on the water surface and can travel fast and long distance. They can be projected on the water between players at a range of 3– 200 feet as there is very little friction slow them on the water surface – particularly the sealed waterball. Each time they bounce, skip or roll on the water surface, the inertia is reduced by opposing forces of gravity, friction, [[surface tension]], [[Drag (physics)|surface drag]].
Waterballs have traditionally been seen as a children's toy, with a number of manufacturers aiming for that particular [[market segment]] when introducing new products. The WaterRipper is being marketed as a kid's 4+ pool toy however it is also marketed as a high-performance action sports water ball. Most waterballs are sold in sporting goods, toy stores, outdoor stores and even food stores. The WaterRipper was launched in the United States in July 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700055506/Outdoor-games-including-safer-versions-of-old-faves-are-simply-good-green-fun.html?pg=all|title = Outdoor games, including safer versions of old faves, are simply good, green fun|last = Arrington|first = Debbie|date = 2010-08-10|website = DeseretNews.com|access-date = 2016-05-14}}</ref> The Waboba ball was initially marketed overseas, introduced in [[Scandinavia]] 2005 and in the [[United Kingdom]] in 2008.<ref name=telegraphball /> It is now sold worldwide.
==Size, shape and materials== The high-performance waterball is generally the size of a [[golf ball]] or stress ball designed for catching with a single hand.<ref name="sacbee">http://www.sacbee.com/2010/07/20/2900977/game-on-the-lawn-outdoor-games.html</ref> Different waterballs are made of different materials. Most high-performance waterballs are sealed balls and are made out of different types of rubber or [[neoprene]] with gel material center and [[polyurethane]] and [[Spandex|Lycra]] jacket.<ref>{{cite web|title=Waterball - Size, Shape and Materials|url=http://www.primidi.com/waterball/size_shape_and_materials}}</ref> The new generation waterball is water absorbing with fluid high-density particulate contents. There are patent pending designs for "high density” or “balanced density " materials in making the new generation waterballs. [[Image:Water Bag being held in hand - size shape.jpg|thumb|alt=Water Bag being held in hand - size and shape.|Water Bag being held in hand - size and shape]]
High-performance waterballs come in different sizes and shapes. There are a handful of high-performance waterballs such as Waboba Ball, Water Bouncer, and the WaterRipper currently sold in the US. The sealed or water absorbing high-performance waterballs are slightly larger + 2” or larger and made of soft rubber generally with a neoprene single seam jacket. These balls are designed to bounce on the water surface.
The water absorbing waterball is the smallest of these high-performance waterballs. It is a collapsing bag or sack like a footbag with an Ultra Suede single seam cover and beaded fill with other water absorbing high-density materials. It is designed to skip and roll on water in a low profile skip pattern. It is less than 2” in diameter and it easily fits and collapses in a 4+ year old’s hand. It looks and feels like a footbag or [[Hacky sack|Hacky Sack]]. The water absorbing waterball like the Waboba Blast Ball and Water Ripper Ball are the only high-performance waterballs designed to absorb water.
===Sealed waterballs vs. absorbent waterballs=== [[Image:Water Bag floating - water absorbing, balanced density design.jpg|thumb|alt=Water Bag floating - water absorbing, balanced density design.|Water Bag floating - water absorbing, balanced density design]] There are actually two types of high-performance waterballs. While all waterballs float on water, there are some that absorb water and others that are sealed. '''Sealed waterballs''' generally bounce higher because they simply repel & displace water. This type of waterball requires the players to have a grip or “timed grab” to catch the ball in flight and stop it. Because they bounce, they are generally hard to catch and often require two hands or a mitt or glove to control or catch them and more suited for adult play.
Conversely, the water absorbing collapsing waterball or waterbag is generally caught with one hand. Because it collapses on impact on the water or in your hand, it is easier and safer to play with young children ages 4+. [[Image:Water bag being thrown.jpg|thumb|alt=Water Bag being thrown - the physics and motion.|Water Bag being thrown - the physics and motion.]]
A sealed ball displaces and bounces on water as it interacts with the water surface. On impact with the water surface or a player's hand, the sealed waterball deforms and deflects and transfers its energy in the opposite direction as it bounces on impact. But a sealed waterball no matter how soft still maintains its spherical shape and ball like properties. The fluid dynamics and shape characteristics are relatively unchanged as the sealed waterball does not change its density.
As such, even [[tennis ball]]s and handballs, [[stress ball]]s can be used as waterball and perform, admitted poorly, depending on force and angle to the water etc.
'''Water absorbing waterballs''' or technically "waterbags", on the other hand, are designed for water and density exchange. Water freely permeates the whole ball, adding more weight and dynamic fluid density. The added weight makes this type of waterball skip and roll on water, rather than bounce. As a result, water absorbing high-performance waterballs travel shorter distances than sealed waterballs but they are easier to control and play with both in long and short range. [[Image:Low profile skip pattern.jpg|thumb|alt=Water Bag being thrown by a player - Low profile skip pattern.|Water Bag being thrown by a player - Low profile skip pattern.]]
A waterbag exchanges its fluid density and transforms and conforms its shape and fluid contents on impact with a surface or plain. On impact with a surface such as water, the waterbag dissipates its energy dynamically as it interacts with the water surface exchanging fluid contents. This changes and balances the bag's density, mass and shape to conform to the water or surface it is performing on as it loses its velocity and comes to rest.
The beanbag-like design of the waterbag changes shape and conforms to a surface thus it collapses and is "slow acting" on impact. There is a significant difference between the physics of the sealed waterball and the water absorbing waterball or waterbag.
The waterbag exchanges its fluid contents on impact and it changes its shape as it collapses on impact. There is no bouncing or minimal bouncing action. Slow acting on impact is an intended design characteristic that is very pleasing and safe in high-speed play action. The "rolling action" of the waterbag that is referred to a "low skip profile" on the water surface that again collapses on impact with the water surface or player's hand. This makes the waterbag less active and easier to catch. The waterbag is both fast in action and slow acting on impact.
==Safety issues== Most waterballs currently available, while perfectly functional in water, are not designed to work well on a hard surface.<ref name="article">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/2484555/Ball-that-bounces-on-water-is-latest-beach-toy.html Ball that bounces on water is latest beach toy - Telegraph<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> This is particularly true with the new generation waterbag design.
The impact of a waterball can hurt, and some waterballs have marks left on their skin.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsreview.com/chico/let-er-rip/content?oid=1438092|title=Let ’er rip - 15 Minutes - Opinions - June 10, 2010|website=Chico News & Review|access-date=2016-05-14}}</ref>
However, there are several balls that address these issues by using softer and lighter material.<ref>http://www.waboba.com</ref> They have a low skip pattern and they are easy to catch and stay in the pool. Water absorbing waterbag designs are also designed in a way that makes them suitable for play in pools.<ref>[http://www.ripperball.com WaterRipper | Ripperball.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Ball games]] [[Category:Water sports]] [[Category:Water toys]]

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = HaYud-Alef Stadium
איצטדיון הי"א | nickname = | image = [[File:Yod alef1.JPG|220px]] | fullname = | location = 6 HaHistadrut Street, Neighborhood A, [[Ashdod]], [[Israel]] 77401 | coordinates = {{coord|31.810525|34.64845|display=inline}} | broke_ground = 1966 | built = | opened = 1966 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Ashdod|Municipality of Ashdod]] | operator = Municipality of Ashdod | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = Maccabi Ashdod (1966–1981)
Beitar Ashdod (1966–1981)
[[Hapoel Ashdod F.C.|Hapoel Ashdod]] (1966–1999)
[[Maccabi Ironi Ashdod F.C.|Ironi Ashdod]] (1981–1999)
[[F.C. Ashdod]] (1999–present) | seating_capacity = 8,200 | dimensions = }} The '''Yud-Alef Stadium''' ({{lang-he|אצטדיון הי"א}}, ''Etztadion HaYudAlef'', lit. ''The 11 Stadium'') is a football [[stadium]] in [[Ashdod]], [[Israel]], that was built for local football sides Maccabi Ashdod, Beitar Ashdod (both merged in 1981 to form [[Maccabi Ironi Ashdod F.C.|Maccabi Ironi Ashdod]]) and [[Hapoel Ashdod F.C.|Hapoel Ashdod]] (merged with Ironi Ashdod in 1999 to create [[F.C. Ashdod]]). The stadium was given the name "Yud-Alef" in 1973, after the eleven Israeli athletes murdered in the [[Munich massacre]] ([[Yodh|Yud]]-[[Aleph|Alef]] is used in [[Hebrew numerals]] used to represent the number 11). The naming ceremony took place on 17 July 1973, when the stadium hosted the final of the [[Football at the 1969 Maccabiah Games|1973 Maccabiah Games]].[http://jhpress.nli.org.il/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=TAUHe&BaseHref=MAR/1973/07/18&PageLabelPrint=11&EntityId=Ar01105&ViewMode=HTML Mexico Didn't Danger the U20's Gold At All] Shmuel Shohat, Ma'ariv, 18 July 1973, Historical Jewish Press {{he icon}} There are four stands in the stadium which is not aesthetically pleasing. The stadium is also thought to be one of the few in the world where the home fans have fewer seats than the visitors. There are a total of 4,000 seats in gates three and four (set aside for visiting supporters). Gates one and two together hold only 3,420 giving the local side a disadvantage when a bigger club comes to town. In a recent article in [[Yedioth Ahronoth]], it was found that the stadium was not built properly and is not safe. The only parts that were deemed safe were the locker rooms and showers. In January 2015 the stadium management unveiled a new a revamped VIP stand.[http://www.mynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4611356,00.html An upgrade at the Stadium: Yes, But Only in the VIP Stand] Yair Harush, 7 January 2015, Mynet.co.il {{he icon}} On 29 August 2006 the fences surrounding the pitch were removed to make for better sightliness for visitors to the stadium.[http://www.one.co.il/cat/articles/article.aspx?id=80514&bz=4 England in Ashdod: Stadium fences removed] One.co.il {{he icon}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{coord|31|48|37|N|34|38|54|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Israeli Premier League}} [[Category:Maccabi Ironi Ashdod F.C.]] [[Category:Hapoel Ashdod F.C.]] [[Category:F.C. Ashdod]] [[Category:Football venues in Israel]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]] [[Category: Buildings and structures in Ashdod|Yud-Alef]] [[Category:Sports venues in Southern District (Israel)]] {{Israel-sports-venue-stub}}
